revision.text:
{{Expand Spanish|date=November 2010|Jesica Cirio}} {{spanish name|Cirio|Perutich}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox model | name = Jessica Cirio | image = Jesica Cirio en un desfile.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = Jessica Cirio on stage in 2011 | birth_name = Jessica Wanda Judith Cirio Perutich | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|3|21}} | birth_place = [[Lanús]], [[Argentina]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Argentine | ethnicity = | occupation = [[Vedette (entertainer)|Vedette]], dancer, model, actress | height = {{height|m=1.70}} | haircolor = Blond | eyecolor = Green | agency = | spouse = {{marriage|Martín Insaurralde|2014}} | children = Chloé Insaurralde (b. November 5, 2017) | website = www.jesicirio.com.ar }}
'''Jessica Wanda Judith Cirio Perutich''' (born March 21, 1985 in [[Lanús]], [[Buenos Aires Province]]) better known as '''Jésica Cirio''' or '''Jessica Cirio''' is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] model and dancer. She has appeared on the Argentine reality show ''[[Cámara en Mano]]'' as well as in [[pictorial]] spreads in ''[[Hombre (magazine)|Revista Hombre]]''.
== Fame == She was the host of ''Kubik'', a TV programme broadcast in [[La Plata]]'s [[Canal 2 (Argentina)|America 2]]. She also took part in two popular Argentine-versions of ShowMatch ''[[Bailando por un sueño (Argentina)|Bailando por un sueño]] in 2006, 2008 and 2012''<ref>[http://www.ciudad.com.ar/espectaculos/75371/jesica-cirio-fue-eliminada-de-bailando-por-un-sueno Jésica Cirio fue eliminada de Bailando por un Sueño]</ref> and ''[[Dancing on Ice around the world#Argentina|Dancing on Ice]]'' also in 2006.<ref>[http://www.diariouno.com.ar/contenidos/2008/11/22/noticia_0009.html Eligieron a los semifinalistas de Patinando]</ref> Cirio has worked many times in [[Chile]] and has also been in [[Fiebre de Baile]].
=== Beginnings === Her first public appearance was in 2001, when she ran for the title of "Diosa Tropical" ("Tropical Goddess") on the television program "Pasión Tropical". Later, she played the role of the niece of Gerardo Sofovich in "Polémica en el Bar". She was also a special guest on "Cámara en Mano".
In 2004, she was chosen to be the hostess of the program "Kubik" for America 2, where she remained until 2009, being replaced by Victoria Vanucci, and then by Ivanna Palliotti, Melina Pitra and Alejandra Maglietti.
=== 2006–2010: ''ShowMatch & Chile'' === In 2006, Cirio participated in the first edition of ''Bailando por un Sueño'', segment of "ShowMatch" for [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]], which made it to the semi-finals. Jésica also participated in other television programs, in roles with which it was becoming more known.
In 2007, she participated in the first edition of ''Patinando por un Sueño'', figure skating competition of the programme "ShowMatch", hosted by [[Marcelo Tinelli]]. The model demonstrated her talent on the track, and reached the semifinals, in which he lost to actress Anita Martínez, but also fulfilled the dream of a dreamer. She left 20 ° between 22 participants.<ref>[http://www.diariouno.com.ar/contenidos/2008/11/22/noticia_0009.html Eligieron a los semifinalistas de Patinando]</ref>
In February 2008, Jessica was invited by [[Chilevisión]] to the programme of celebrity gossip and entertainment SQP where she covered the details of the Festival of [[Viña del Mar]], in Chile.
In 2008, she again took part in the fifth edition of Bailando por un Sueño.<ref>[http://www.ciudad.com.ar/espectaculos/75371/jesica-cirio-fue-eliminada-de-bailando-por-un-sueno Jésica Cirio fue eliminada de Bailando por un Sueño]</ref>
In 2009, Jessica returned to Chile to participate in ''Fiebre de Baile'' and the series ''Infieles'' and ''Teatro en Chilevision''.
Cirio in late-2009 debuted as the first vedette of the [[music hall]], "Carnaval de Estrellas" in the province of [[Villa Carlos Paz]]. The musical's main cast was (in order of figures): [[Valeria Lynch]] later Estela Raval, Raúl Lavié, Jessica Cirio, Flavio Mendoza, Juan Carlos Calabró, Marcos "Bicho" Gómez, Martín "Campi" Campilongo, "Pepa" Brizuela, Florencia "Floppy" Tesouro, Sabrina Artaza, Pabla Thomen, Marikena Cornejo and cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcelopendola.com/index.php/carnaval-de-las-estrellas/|title=Carnaval de las Estrellas|language=Spanish}}</ref> Produced by "Jordan Productions" with Andrea Stivel and Daniel Comba, creators. Choreographes by Hugo Gómez and Vanina Befaro while Beto Romano was the designer of the costumes. The musical debuted on December 18, 2009 in theater, Candilejas I.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.extremista.com.ar/46940/carnaval-de-estrellas-en-villa-carlos-paz/|title="Carnaval de Estrellas" en Villa Carlos Paz|date=November 26, 2009|accessdate=January 9, 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In 2010 she was invited to the program ''Así Somos'' by the Chilean TV channel [[La Red (Chilean TV channel)|La Red]] and then she hosted with Roberto Menna (Bobby) Impacto 9 by [[Canal 9 (Argentina)|Canal 9]] and participate in Bailando por un Sueño 2010, in which she was eliminated but was already planning to get off the competition because of the death of her former boyfriend. [[Image:Jesicacirio en Imapcto9.jpg|thumb|right|Jessica in Impact 9]]
=== 2011–Present: ''Excitante & Noche de Astros'' === From late-2011 through early-2012 Jésica Cirio was in the theatre musical [[Excitante]]. The show presented itself in the theatre of Mar del Plata. The producer was Daniel Comba and the show was led and presented by Miguel Ángel Cherutti and Nito Artaza.
The musical finished in its fourth musical cycle and with Cirio as the co-lead vedette after supervedette [[Adabel Guerrero]].<ref>{{cite web| url= http://teleshow.infobae.com/notas/608206-Las-diosas-que-se-juntaron-para-conquistar-el-verano|title= Las diosas que se juntaron para conquistar el verano| date= September 2011 | publisher= Teleshow de [[Infobae]] | accessdate= 5 October 2011}}</ref> The show was formed by Adabel Guerrero, Jésica Cirio, [[Estefanía Bacca]], Alejandra Maglietti, Cinthia Fernández & [[Virginia Dobrich]] as well as Miguel Ángel Cherutti and Nito Artaza also Marcos “Bicho” Gómez, the late Estela Raval with Los 5 Latinos and Adrián Kiss the shows lead male dancer and acrobat.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://teleshow.infobae.com/notas/606144-Dos-diosas-juntas-en-el-teatro|title=¿Dos diosas estarán juntas en teatro? | date=September 2011 | publisher= Teleshow de [[Infobae]]| accessdate= 5 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.primiciasya.com/noticias-quienes-seran-las-chicas-que-estaran-con-nito-artaza-y-miguel-angel-cherutti-93875.html| title= ¿Quiénes serán las chicas que estarán con Nito Artaza y Miguel Ángel Cherutti?| date= 28 September 11| publisher= Primicias Ya| accessdate= 5 October 2011| deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111001133629/http://www.primiciasya.com/noticias-quienes-seran-las-chicas-que-estaran-con-nito-artaza-y-miguel-angel-cherutti-93875.html| archivedate= 1 October 2011| df= }}</ref>
On November 2, 2012 the model made an appearance for the river border state of Argentina to Uruguay, [[Entre Ríos Province]] in the '''''Astros''''' theater where she and many other theater artist presented Entre Ríos' summer theatrical season debut for 2012 and 2013 with three shows, one in which she starred as the lead vedette in a [[Revue|theater magazine]], '''''"Noche de Astros"'''''. Cirio has abandoned the magazine for unknown reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cndigital.com.ar/noticias/20903_se-presento-en-buenos-aires-la-primera-temporada-teatral-de-entre-rios-con-cartelera-nacional.html|title=Se presentó en Buenos Aires la primera temporada teatral de Entre Ríos con cartelera nacional.|date=November 2, 2012|accessdate=November 23, 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.26noticias.com.ar/santiago-bal-volvio-al-escenario-y-se-emociono-con-al-aplauso-161224.html|title=Santiago Bal volvió al escenario y se emocionó con al aplauso: Fue en la presentación de la temporada teatral de verano 2012 – 2013 de Entre Ríos.|date=November 2, 2012|accessdate=November 23, 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref>
On November 6, 2014 the model married politician [[Martín Insaurralde]] for the civil registration in the [[Lomas de Zamora]] city, and November 8, 2014 they celebrated bride of La Manea Polo Club in Tristán Suarez town.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
== Trajectory ==
=== Television === # 1999 – Pasión tropical – América TV – Video. # 1999 – [[Polémica en el Bar]] (segmento) – Canal 9 – niece # 2004/2009 – [[Kubik (comics)|Kubik]] – [[América 2]] – Hostess. # 2005 – [[Noche de juegos]] – [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]] – guest # 2006 – [[Bailando por un sueño]] – [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]] – competitor (7/9) # 2006 – Cámara en Mano – special guest. # 2007 – [[Patinando por un sueño]] – [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]] – competitor (20/22). # 2008 – [[SQP (TV series)|SQP]] (Chile) – [[Chilevisión]] – Special journalist of the Festival of Viña del Mar # 2008 – [[Bailando por un sueño]] – [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]] – competitor (32/42). # 2008 – [[Teatro en Chilevisión]] – Chilevisión – actress # 2009 – [[Fiebre de baile]] – Chilevisión – competitor # 2009 – [[Infieles]] – Chilevisión – actress # 2010 – [[Así somos]] – [[La Red (Chilean TV channel)|La Red]] – special guest # 2010 – [[Impacto 9]] – [[Canal 9 (Argentina)|Canal 9]] – hostess # 2010 – [[Bailando por un Sueño]] – [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]] – competitor (19/31). # 2012 – [[Am, Antes del Mediodia|AM]] – [[Telefe]] – guest # 2014 – [[Bailando por un Sueño]] – [[El Trece (Argentina)|Canal 13]] – current competitor
=== Theatre === # 2009–2010 – "Carnaval de Estrellas" ([[Valeria Lynch]], Raúl Lavie and Flavio Mendoza) – Teatro Candileja I ([[Villa Carlos Paz]]) – Replaced by [[Adabel Guerrero]]. # 2011–2012 – "[[Excitante]]" (Estela Raval, [[Adabel Guerrero]], Nito Artaza and Miguel Ángel Cherutti) – [[Mar del Plata]]. # 2012 – "Noche de Astros" (Miguel Ángel Cherutti and Marcos "Bicho" Gómez) – Teatro Astros ([[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]]) – Abandoned.
== See also == *[[List of glamour models]]

revision.text:
[[File:Lament for ur (cropped).JPG|thumb|Lament for Ur at the [[Louvre Museum]] in [[Paris]]]] [[File:Flickr - The U.S. Army - Soldiers explore the biblical home of Abraham.jpg|thumb|Reconstructed ruins of the city of Ur]] [[File:Ziggarat of Ur 001.jpg|thumb|Ziggurat of Ur]] [[File:Ancient ziggurat at Ali Air Base Iraq 2005.jpg|thumb|U.S. Soldiers on the Ziggurat of Ur]]
{{Mesopotamian myth (7)}}
The '''Lament for Ur''', or '''Lamentation over the city of Ur''' is a [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]] [[lament]] composed around the time of the fall of [[Ur]] to the [[Elamites]] and the end of the city's [[Third Dynasty of Ur|third dynasty]] (c. 2000 BC).
==Laments==
It contains one of five known [[Mesopotamia]]n "city laments"—[[dirge]]s for ruined cities in the voice of the city's [[tutelary deity|tutelary goddess]].
The other city laments are: *The [[Lament for Sumer and Ur]] *The [[Lament for Nippur]] *The [[Lament for Eridu]] *The [[Lament for Uruk]]
The [[Book of Lamentations]] of the [[Old Testament]], which bewails the destruction of [[Jerusalem]] by [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] of [[Babylon]] in the sixth century B.C., is similar in style and theme to these earlier [[Mesopotamia]]n laments. Similar laments can be found in the [[Book of Jeremiah]], the [[Book of Ezekiel]] and the [[Book of Psalms]], [[Psalm 137]] ({{Bibleverse||Psalms|137:1-9|HE}}), a song covered by [[Boney M]] in 1978 as [[Rivers of Babylon]].<ref name="MatthewsBenjamin2006">{{cite book|author1=[[Victor Harold Matthews]]|author2=Don C. Benjamin|title=Old Testament parallels: laws and stories from the ancient Near East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6gVAFOSDhL4C&pg=PA248|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=2006|publisher=Paulist Press|isbn=978-0-8091-4435-8|pages=248–}}</ref>
==Compilation==
The first lines of the lament were discovered on the [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]] catalogue of the [[Babylonia]]n section, tablet numbers 2204, 2270, 2302 and 19751 from their excavations at the [[temple]] [[library]] at [[Nippur]]. These were translated by [[George Aaron Barton]] in 1918 and first published as "Sumerian religious texts" in ''[[Miscellaneous Babylonian Inscriptions]]'', number six, entitled "A prayer for the city of [[Ur]]".<ref name="Barton1918">{{cite book|author=George Aaron Barton|title=Miscellaneous Babylonian inscriptions, p. 45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nn5hAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=1918|publisher=Yale University Press}}</ref> The restored tablet is {{convert|9|by|4.5|by|1.75|in|cm}} at its thickest point. Barton noted that "from the portions that can be translated it appears to be a prayer for the city of Ur at a time of great danger and distress. It seems impossible to assign it with certainty to any particular period." He noted that it was plausible but unconfirmed to conjecture that it "was written in the last days of [[Ibbi-Sin]] when Ur was tottering to its fall".<ref name="Barton1918"/>
[[Edward Chiera]] published other tablets CBS 3878, 6889, 6905, 7975, 8079, 10227, 13911 and 14110 in "Sumerian texts of varied contents" in 1934, which combined with tablets CBS 3901, 3927, 8023, 9316, 11078 and 14234 to further restore the myth, calling it a "Lamentation over the city of Ur".<ref name="ChieraKramer1934">{{cite book|author1=Edward Chiera|author2=Samuel Noah Kramer|author3=University of Pennsylvania. University Museum. Babylonian Section|title=Sumerian texts of varied contents, p. 1-|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZHhiAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=3 June 2011|date=1934|publisher=The University of Chicago Press}}</ref> A further tablet source of the myth is held by the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]], number AO 6446.<ref name="antiqueorientales">{{cite book|author1=Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités orientales et de la céramique antique|author2=Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités orientales|title=Textes cunéiformes, 16, 40|publisher=Librairie orientaliste, Paul Geuthner}}</ref> Others are held in the [[Ashmolean]], [[Oxford]], numbers 1932,415, 1932,522, 1932,526j and 1932,526o.<ref name="Museum">{{cite book|author1=Ashmolean Museum|title=Oxford Editions of Cuneiform Texts, 12, 13, 14 and 15|date=1976|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> Further tablets were found to be part of the myth in the [[Hermann Volrath Hilprecht|Hilprecht]] collection at the [[University of Jena]], [[Germany]], numbers 1426, 1427, 1452, 1575, 1579, 1487, 1510 and 1553.<ref name="Antiquities">{{cite book|author=Universität. Jena. Frau Professor Hilprecht Collection of Babylonian Antiquities|title=Texte und Materialien der Frau-Professor-Hilprecht-Collection of Babylonian antiquities: Neue Folge, 4 18, 4 19, 4 21, 4 20, 4 22, 4 23, 4 24 and 4 25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0QK1YgEACAAJ|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=Hinrichs}}</ref> More fragments are held at the [[Musée d'Art et d'Histoire (Geneva)]] in [[Switzerland]], MAH 15861 and MAH 16015.<ref name="Literatures1970">{{cite book|author=University of Chicago. Dept. of Oriental Languages and Literatures|title=Journal of Near Eastern studies, pl. 1 and 2|date=1970|publisher=Univ. of Chicago Press.}}</ref>
Other translations were made from tablets in the Nippur collection of the [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums|Museum of the Ancient Orient]] in [[Istanbul]] (Ni). [[Samuel Noah Kramer]] amongst others worked to translate several others from the Istanbul collection including Ni 4496, 1162, 2401, 2510, 2518, 2780, 2911, 3166, 4024, 4424, 4429, 4459, 4474, 4566, 9586, 9599, 9623, 9822 and 9969.<ref name="Kramer1944">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=Sumerian literary texts from Nippur: in the Museum of the Ancient Orient at Istanbul, 32, 45, 94, 95, 96, 97, 98 and 99|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqdIGQAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1944|publisher=American Schools of Oriental Research}}</ref><ref name="CigKizilyay1969">{{cite book|author1=Muazzez Cig|author2=Hatice Kizilyay|title=Sumerian literary tablets and fragments in the archeological museum of Istanbul-I, 81, 95, 100, 107, 115, 118, 139, 142 and 147|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vrEnGwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1969|publisher=Tarih Kurumu Basimevi}}</ref> Other tablets from the Istanbul collection, numbers Ni 2510 and 2518 were translated by Edward Chiera in 1924 in "Sumerian religious texts".<ref name="Chieraottoman1924">{{cite book|author1=Edward Chiera|author2=Constantinople. Musée impérial ottoman|title=Sumerian religious texts, 32 & 45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8BF3QgAACAAJ|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=1924|publisher=University}}</ref> Sir [[Charles Leonard Woolley]] unearthed more tablets at [[Ur]] contained in the "Ur excavations texts" from 1928.<ref name="Mesopotamiamuseum1928">{{cite book|author1=British museum and Pennsylvania University. University museum. Joint expedition to Mesopotamia|author2=Pennsylvania University. University museum|title=Ur excavations texts... 6 137, 6 135, 6 136, 6 137, 6 138, 6 139, 6 *290|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4GF1QwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1928|publisher=British museum}}</ref> Other tablets are held in the [[Vorderasiatisches Museum Berlin]] and the [[Yale]] Babylonian collection.<ref name="AbteilungZimmern1966">{{cite book|author1=Königliche Museen zu Berlin. Vorderasiatische Abteilung|author2=Heinrich Zimmern|author3=Otto Schroeder|author4=H. H. Figulla |author5=Wilhelm Förtsch |author6=Friedrich Delitzsch |title=Vorderasiatische Schriftdenkmäler 10, 141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZA5mYgEACAAJ|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=Louis D. Levine}}</ref> [[Samuel Noah Kramer]] compiled twenty-two different fragments into the first complete edition of the ''Lament'', which was published in 1940 by the [[University of Chicago]] as ''Lamentation over the Destruction of Ur'' (''Assyriological Study'' no. 12). Other tablets and versions were used to bring the myth to its present form with a composite text by Miguel Civil produced in 1989 and latest translations by [[Thorkild Jacobsen]] in 1987 and Joachim Krecher in 1996.<ref name="ETCSL">[http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/etcsl.cgi?text=t.2.2.2&charenc=j# The Lament for Ur., Black, J.A., Cunningham, G., Robson, E., and Zólyomi, G., The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature, Oxford 1998-.]</ref><ref>[http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/etcsl.cgi?text=c.4.80.2&display=Crit&charenc=&lineid=c4802.B.22#c4802.B.22 ETCSLtransliteration : c.4.80.2]</ref>
==Composition==
The lament is composed of four hundred and thirty eight lines in eleven ''kirugu'' (sections), arranged in [[stanza]]s of six lines. It describes the goddess [[Ningal]], who weeps for her city after pleading with the god [[Enlil]] to call back a destructive storm. Interspersed with the goddess's wailing are other sections, possibly of different origin and composition; these describe the [[ghost town]] that Ur has become, recount the wrath of Enlil's storm, and invoke the protection of the god [[Nanna (Sumerian deity)|Nanna]] ([[Nergal]] or [[Suen]]) against future calamities. Ningal, the wife of the moon god Nanna, goes on to recall her petition to the leaders of the gods, [[Anu|An]] and [[Enlil]] to change their minds and not to destroy Ur.<ref name="Launderville2003">{{cite book|author=Dale Launderville|title=Piety and politics: the dynamics of royal authority in Homeric Greece, biblical Israel, and old Babylonian Mesopotamia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z4oHNWUWTSkC&pg=PA248|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=2003|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-3994-7|pages=248–}}</ref> She does this both in private and in a speech to the [[Annunaki]] assembly:
{{cquote|I verily clasped legs, laid hold of arms, truly I shed my tears before An, truly I made supplication, I myself before Enlil: "May my city not be ravaged, I said to them, May Ur not be ravaged.<ref name="Launderville2003"/>}}
The [[wikt:council|council]] of gods decide that the Ur III dynasty, which had reigned for around one hundred years, had its destiny apportioned to end. The temple [[treasury]] was raided by invading [[Elam]]ites and the centre of power in Sumer moved to Isin, while control of trade in Ur passed to several leading families of the city. Kenneth Wade suggested that [[Terah]], the father of [[Abraham]] in the [[Book of Genesis]] could have been one of the heads of such a leading family ({{Bibleverse||Genesis|11:28|HE}}).<ref name="Wade2004">{{cite book|author=Kenneth R. Wade|title=Journey to Moriah: The Untold Story of How Abraham Became the Friend of God|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a9tiuu1byC8C&pg=PA21|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=February 2004|publisher=Pacific Press Publishing|isbn=978-0-8163-2024-0|pages=21–}}</ref> The [[metaphor]] of a [[garden]] [[hut (dwelling)|hut]] being knocked down is used for the destroyed temple of Ur and in subsequent lines this metaphorical language is extended to the rest of the setting, reminiscent of the representation of Jerusalem as a "booth" in the [[Book of Amos]] ({{Bibleverse||Amos|9:11|HE}}).<ref name="EllensEllens2004">{{cite book|author1=J. Harold Ellens|author2=Deborah L. Ellens|author3=Rolf P. Knierim|author4=Isaac Kalimi|title=God's Word for Our World: Biblical studies in honor of Simon John De Vries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tMKRgS6G9xUC&pg=PA287|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=2004|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-8264-6974-8|pages=287–}}</ref> Ningal bewails:
{{cquote|My faithful house ... like a tent, a pulled-up harvest shed, like a pulled-up harvest shed! Ur, my home filled with things, my well-filled house and city that were pulled up, were verily pulled up.<ref name="EllensEllens2004"/>}}
The different temples throughout the land are described with their patron gods or goddesses abandoning the temples, like [[sheepfold]]s:
{{cquote|[[Ninlil]] has abandoned that house, the Ki-ur, and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. The queen of [[Kesh (Sumer)|Kesh]] has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. Ninmah has abandoned that house Kesh and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold.<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
Edward L. Greenstein has noted the emptying of sheep pens as a metaphor of the destruction of the city. He also notes that the speakers of the laments are generally male lamentation-priests, who take on the characteristics of a traditional female singer and ask for the gods to be appeased so the temples can be restored. Then a goddess, sometimes accompanied by a god notes the devastation and weeps bitterly with a dirge about the destructive storm and an entreats to the gods to return to the sanctuaries. The destruction of the Elamites is compared in the myth to imagery of a rising [[flood]] and raging [[storm]]. This imagery is facilitated by the title of Enlil as the "god of the winds"<ref name="Weisman2010">{{cite book|author=Karen Weisman|title=The Oxford handbook of the elegy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1d5OlvBRc38C&pg=PA75|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=6 June 2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-922813-3|pages=75–}}</ref> The following text suggests that the setting of the myth was subject to a destructive storm prior to its final destruction:<ref name="Louvain1977">{{cite book|author=Institut orientaliste de Louvain|title=Orientalia Lovaniensia periodica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GOZtAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=1977|publisher=Instituut voor Oriëntalistiek.}}</ref>
{{cquote|Alas, storm after storm swept the Land together: the great storm of heaven, the ever-roaring storm, the malicious storm which swept over the Land, the storm which destroyed cities, the storm which destroyed houses, the storm which destroyed cow-pens, the storm which burned sheepfolds, which laid hands on the holy rites, which defiled the weighty counsel, the storm which cut off all that is good from the Land.<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
Various buildings are noted to be destroyed in Enlil's storm, including the shrines of Agrun-kug and Egal-mah, the [[Ekur]] (the sanctuary of Enlil), the Iri-kug, the Eridug and the Unug.<ref name="ETCSL"/> The destruction of the E-kic-nu-jal is described in detail. {{cquote|The good house of the lofty untouchable mountain, E-kic-nu-jal, was entirely devoured by large axes. The people of Cimacki and Elam, the destroyers, counted its worth as only thirty shekels. They broke up the good house with pickaxes. They reduced the city to ruin mounds.<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
Images of what was lost, and the scorched earth that was left behind indicate the scale of the catastrophe. The Line 274 reads {{cquote|"[[Garden of Eden|eden]] kiri-zal bi du-du-a-mu gir-gin ha-ba-hu-hur" - My [[steppe]], established for [[joy]], was scorched like an [[oven]].<ref name="Michalowski1989"/>}}
The destruction of the location is reported to Enlil, and his consort Ninlil, who are praised and exalted at the end of the myth.<ref name="Ramet1996">{{cite book|author=Sabrina P. Ramet|title=Gender reversals and gender cultures: anthropological and historical perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZDalL3qJavgC&pg=PA58|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=1996|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-11482-0|pages=58–}}</ref>
==Discussion==
The Lament for Ur has been well known to scholarship and well edited for a long time. Piotr Michalowski has suggested this gave literary primacy to the myth over the [[Lament for Sumer and Ur]], originally called the "Second Lament for Ur", which he argues was chronologically a more archaic version.<ref name="Michalowski1989">{{cite book|author=Piotr Michalowski|title=The lamentation over the destruction of Sumer and Ur|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=te_g2xGYIFEC&pg=PA4|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=1989|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=978-0-931464-43-0|pages=4–}}</ref> Philip S. Alexander compares lines seventeen and eighteen of the myth with {{Bibleverse|Lamentations|2:17|HE}} "The Lord has done what he purposed, he has carried out his threat; as he ordained long ago, he has demolished without pity", suggesting this could "allude to some mysterious, ineluctable fate ordained for [[Zion]] in the distant past":
{{cquote|The wild bull of Eridug has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. Enki has abandoned that house Eridug and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold.<ref name="Alexander2007">{{cite book|author=Philip S. Alexander|title=The Targum of Lamentations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kmUaWZy6JZQC&pg=PA26|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=1 December 2007|publisher=Liturgical Press|isbn=978-0-8146-5864-2|pages=26–}}</ref>}}
The devastation of cities and settlements by natural disasters and invaders has been used widely throughout the history of literature since the end of the [[Third Dynasty of Ur]]. A stela (pictured) from [[Iraq]] depicts a similar destruction of a mountain house at [[Susa]].
{{cquote|Dead men, not potsherds. Covered the approaches. The walls were gaping, the high gates, the roads, were piled with dead. In the side streets, where feasting crows would gather, scattered they lay. In all the side streets and roadways bodies lay. In the open fields that used to fill with dancers, they lay in heaps. The country's blood now filled its holes, like metal in a mould; Bodies dissolved - like fat left in the sun.<ref name="Tsouras2005">{{cite book|author=Peter G. Tsouras|title=The Book of Military Quotations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BDgnD0omDo0C&pg=PA12|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=24 October 2005|publisher=Zenith Imprint|isbn=978-0-7603-2340-3|pages=12–}}</ref>}}
Michelle Breyer suggested tribes of neighbouring [[shepherd]]s destroyed the city and called Ur, "the last great city to fall".<ref name="Breyer1997">{{cite book|author=Michelle Breyer|title=Ancient Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f3bFW1qY8eYC&pg=PA41|accessdate=4 June 2011|date=December 1997|publisher=Teacher Created Resources|isbn=978-1-55734-573-8|pages=41–}}</ref>

The [[Poland|Polish]] film industry produced over one hundred feature films in [[2017 in film|2017]]. This article fully lists all non-pornographic films, including short films, that had a release date in that year and which were at least partly made by [[Polish language|Polish]]. It does not include films first released in previous years that had release dates in 2017. [[File:Dougal++Gammer.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[DJ Dougal]] and [[Gammer]].]] This is a list of notable club [[DJ]]s, professionals who perform, or are known to perform, at large nightclub venues or other dance events, or who have been pioneers in the development of the role of the club DJ. DJs play a mix of recorded [[music]] for an audience at a bar, [[nightclub]], [[dance club]] or [[rave]] who dance to the music. The music is played through a [[sound reinforcement system]].
DJs who use their real names are listed alphabetically by last name; DJs who use stage names are listed alphabetically by their first name.
==#== *[[3 Are Legend]] *[[3LAU]] (real name Justin Blau), American [[progressive house]] and [[electro house]] DJ and producer.
==A== [[File:Armin van Buuren 2017 (5).jpg|thumb|right|[[Armin van Buuren]]]] *[[A-Trak]] *[[Adam Beyer]] Famous Swedish [[techno]] DJ and producer and boss of the influential [[Drumcode Records]] label. *[[Adventure Club]] *[[Aero Chord]] *[[Afrojack]] (real name Nick van de Wall), Dutch House DJ/Producer *[[Alan Walker (producer)|Alan Walker]] *[[Albatraoz]] *[[Alesso]] *[[Alexander Perls]] *[[Alice Deejay]] *[[All Hail the Silence]] *[[Allessandro Benassi]] *[[Alok (DJ)]] *[[Alvaro (DJ)]] *[[André Marques]] Brazilian DJ, TV presenter and Actor. *[[Angger Dimas]] Indonesian electronic musician, DJ/Producer, called the #1 DJ of Indonesia by thedjlist.com *[[Armin van Buuren]]<!--Following Dutch sorting convention, which ignores particles such as "van"--> (born 1976), Dutch trance DJ/producer. The only DJ who has been named number one DJ in the world 5 times on DJ Magazine's Top 100 DJ poll *[[Armand van Helden]] *[[AronChupa]] *[[ATB]] (real name André Tanneberger, born 1973), German Trance & Light Trance DJ/Producer *[[Audien]](real name Nate Rathbun, born 1992) American Trance & House DJ/producer known for Pompeii remix *[[Avicii]] (real name Tim Bergling, 1989–2018), Swedish house DJ/producer best known for "Levels" *[[Axwell]] (real name Axel Hedfors, born 1977), Swedish house DJ/producer best known as a member of the [[Swedish House Mafia]] *[[Axwell & Ingrosso]] *[[Andrew Rayel]] (born 1992), Moldovan Trance DJ/Producer *[[Ansel Elgort|Ansolo]] American DJ/producer and actor who portrayed Augustus Waters in ''[[The Fault In Our Stars]]'' *[[Aubrey (producer)]]
==B== *[[Bass Bumpers]] (also known as CJ Stone, and Bad Habit Boys), German Trance and techno DJ group *[[Bassjackers]] *[[Bassnectar]] *[[Basto]] *[[Benassi Bros.]] *[[Benny Benassi]] *[[Randy Bettis]] *[[Bingo Players]] *[[Blasterjaxx]], (Thom Jongkind and Idir Makhlaf), Dutch Electro House and Big Room House *[[The Bloody Beetroots]] *[[Bob Sinclar]] (born Christophe Le Friant; 10 May 1969), [[French people|French]] [[record producer]], [[house music]] [[Disc jockey|DJ]], [[remix]]er, he is a two time [[DJ Awards]] winner and also the owner of the [[record label|label]] [[Yellow Productions]].<ref>IMO Records. [http://www.imorecords.co.uk/house-2/house-artists/bob-sinclar-biography/ "Bob Sinclar Biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120911175844/http://www.imorecords.co.uk/house-2/house-artists/bob-sinclar-biography/ |date=2012-09-11 }}, ''IMO Records'', London, Retrieved on 25 January 2012.</ref> *[[Boom Jinx]] (real name Øistein Johan Eide), composer, producer and DJ from Norway *[[Borgeous]] *[[Borgore]] *[[Mark Brain]] *[[Bro Safari]]
==C== *[[Calvin Harris]] (real name Adam Wiles, born 1984), Scottish DJ/producer *[[Carnage (DJ)|Carnage]] (real name Diamanté Anthony Blackmon, born January 3, 1991), Guatemalan-American DJ and record producer *[[The Chainsmokers]] *[[Chris Liebing]], German DJ known for playing a decisive role in shaping the hardcore [[techno]] genre ''Schranz''. *[[Chuckie (DJ)|Chuckie]] (real name Clyde Sergio Narain), Dutch House DJ/Producer *[[Claptone]] *[[Cosmic Gate]], German Progressive Trance, electronic DJ/Producer *[[Cash Cash]] *[[The Chemical Brothers]], duo DJs from UK. *[[Carl Cox]] (born 1962), genres include house, tech house, techno, minimal techno winner of [[DJ Magazine|DJ Magazine's]] Worlds No. 1 DJ Award in 1996 and 1997 he is also an 11 time [[DJ Awards]] winner. *[[The Crystal Method]], duo DJs from America, known for their "Vegas" CD *[[Chris Leão]] (Real name Christian Leão), electronic music producer and Brazilian DJ.

[[Image:Deadmau5 - at the Paramount Theater in Seattle Washington.jpg|thumb|right|[[Deadmau5]]]] *[[DVBBS]] *[[DJ Asumadu]] *[[David M. Solomon|DJ D-Sol]] (D-Sol) *[[DallasK]] *[[Danny Dyer]] alias Pwoper Nawty (born 1977), DJ and MC *[[Danny Rampling]], widely credited as one of the original founders of the UK's rave/club scene.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Warren|first1=Emma|title=The birth of rave|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/aug/12/electronicmusic|website=12 August 2007|publisher=The Observer Newspaper London|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> He was the first No 1 DJ in the world voted by the staff of [[DJ Magazine]] in 1991 in 1997 the top 100 poll became a public vote. *[[Danny Tenaglia]] "Daniel" (born March 7, 1961), New York-based DJ and [[Grammy]] nominated record producer he is also a 3 time [[IDMA]] winner and 3 time [[DJ Awards]] winner *[[Darude]] (real name Ville Virtanen, born 1975), originally from Finland. *[[Datsik (musician)|Datsik]] *[[David Grutman]] *[[David Guetta]], French DJ *[[David Mancuso]], (born October 20, 1944), DJ/Promoter created the popular "by invitation only" parties in New York City known as "The Loft Parties" many famous private discothèques/clubs of the '70s and '80s were modeled after [[The Loft (New York City)|The Loft]], including the [[Paradise Garage]], [[The Gallery (disco)|The Gallery]], and [[Saint (nightclub)|The Saint]]. *[[David Morales]] (born 21 August 1961), internationally acclaimed [[Grammy]]-winning American house music DJ and [[Record producer|producer]]. *[[David Vendetta]] *[[Deadmau5]] (real name Joel Thomas Zimmerman, born 1981), Canadian House DJ/Producer. *[[Dillon Francis]] *[[Diplo]], American DJ, record producer, rapper, singer, songwriter and record executive (Also works in collaboration with Skrillex as Jack Ü) *[[Dirty South (musician)|Dirty South]] *[[Debris (DJ)]] *[[Deorro]] *[[Derrick Carter]] *[[Derrick May (musician)]] *[[Detroit Grand Pubahs]] *[[DJ Hell]], Internationally acclaimed German DJ and boss of [[International DeeJay Gigolo Records|International Deejay Gigolos]]. to the Congress regarding low-power FM service, and for other purposes. | colloquialacronym = | nickname = | enacted by = 111th | effective date = | public law url = | cite public law = | cite statutes at large = <!--{{usstat}} can be used--> | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = <!--US code titles changed--> | sections created = <!--{{USC}} can be used--> | sections amended = | leghisturl = | introducedin = <!--House or Senate--> | introducedbill = | introducedby = <!--sponsor(s)--> | introduceddate = | committees = | passedbody1 = | passeddate1 = | passedvote1 = | passedbody2 = | passedas2 = <!-- used if the second body changes the name of the legislation --> | passeddate2 = | passedvote2 = | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreeddate3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedvote3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedbody4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreeddate4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreedvote4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = | signeddate = | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Local Community Radio Act''' is an [[Act of Congress|act]] of [[broadcast law]] in the [[United States]], explicitly authorizing the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) to license local [[low-power broadcasting]] in the [[FM broadcast]] [[band (radio)|band]] (LPFM). After five years and four versions, it passed the [[U.S. Congress]] in 2010, granting [[equal protection]] to [[community radio]] stations with regard to [[broadcast translator|translator]] and [[single-frequency network|booster]] stations. All three types of stations remain secondary to full-power [[radio station]]s, which are typically owned by major corporations and [[nonprofit]]s. (Previously, this second-class status was only a part of FCC regulation, rather than law.) The act negates the Radio Broadcasting Preservation Act of 2000, which enacted prevented community LPFM stations on the basis of [[RF interference]].
==Versions==
===Local Community Radio Act of 2005=== * Introduced by U.S. Senators [[John McCain]], [[Maria Cantwell]], [[Patrick Leahy]] * After the FCC complied with the provisions of the Radio Broadcasting Act of 2000 by commissioning [https://web.archive.org/web/20101124200511/http://fcc.gov/oet/info/mitrereport/ the MITRE Report] to test if there was significant interference from LPFM stations on the full-power stations, the study showed that the interference of LPFM is minimal and won't have a significant effect on other stations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.current.org/tech/tech0314lpfm.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525090155/http://www.current.org/tech/tech0314lpfm.html |archivedate=2011-05-25 |df= }}</ref> * According to Sen. Leahy, "This bill will open up the airwaves to truly local broadcasting while protecting full-power broadcasters from unreasonable interference and preserving important services such as reading services for the blind."<ref>http://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=8904246a-cd92-489c-81b1-48d8eddc4298</ref>
===Local Community Radio Act of 2007===
Sponsored in the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] by Congressmen [[Mike Doyle (Pennsylvania politician)|Mike Doyle]] and [[Lee Terry]] and in the [[U.S. Senate]] by Senators [[Maria Cantwell]] and [[John McCain]] the Local Community Radio Act of 2007 failed to be voted on. The House bill, H.R. 2802, was referred to the Subcommittee on Telecommunications and the Internet on June 21, 2007.<ref name="govtrack.us">GovTrack.us. (2007) "H.R. 2802: Local Community Radio Act of 2007." ''GovTrack.us.'' Retrieved February 12, 2008, from http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-2802</ref> Since the bill was not passed in FY 2007, the bill was removed from the docket as Never Passed.
===Local Community Radio Act of 2009=== This bill was an update of the Local Community Radio Act of 2007. It required FCC to alter current rules in order to eliminate the minimum distance separation between low-power FM stations and third-[[adjacent channel|adjacent-channel]] stations.<ref name="ww-111hr1147">WashingtonWatch.com. (2009) "H.R. 1147, The Local Community Radio Act of 2009." "WashingtonWatch.com." Retrieved May 23, 2009, from http://www.washingtonwatch.com/bills/show/111_HR_1147.html#toc2</ref> Previously, there had been a minimum distance requirement, however the FCC found that LPFM stations did not cause any interference on third-adjacent channel stations, thus eliminating the need for such a requirement.<ref>RADIO magazine - The Radio Technology Leader. (2004) "FCC Reports LPFM Interference Findings to Congress." "Media Access Project." Retrieved May 24, 2009, from {{cite web |url=http://www.mediaaccess.org/programs/lpfm/RADIOmagazine.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409100247/http://www.mediaaccess.org/programs/lpfm/RADIOmagazine.pdf |archivedate=2008-04-09 |df= }}</ref>
The Local Community Radio Act of 2009 also required that the FCC keep the rules that offer interference protection to third-adjacent channels that offer a [[radio reading service]] (the reading of newspapers, books or magazines for those who are blind or hearing impaired.)<ref>KPBS Radio Reading Service. "About." "KPBS." Retrieved May 23, 2009, from http://kpbsreadingservice.org</ref> This protection was to ensure that such channels are not subject to possible interference by LPFM stations.<ref name="govtrack.us"/>
The final part of the bill required that when giving out licenses to FM stations, the FCC must make licenses available to LPFM stations and that licensing decisions be made with regard to local community needs.<ref name="ww-111hr1147"/>
The bill had unanimous bipartisan support from FCC leadership.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQ4TC9Aqjfc |title=FCC: Unanimous, bipartisan support for LPFM |date=September 18, 2009 |author=[[United States Congress]] |publisher=[[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]] }}</ref> It was passed by the House and referred to the Senate.
===Local Community Radio Act of 2010=== The Local Community Radio Act of 2010 (based upon legislation originally introduced in 2005) was signed into law by President [[Barack Obama]] on January 4, 2011 as {{USPL|111|371}}, after passage in the House on December 17, 2010, and the U.S. Senate on December 18, 2010. In a statement after the bill became law, Federal Communications Commission Chair Julius Genachowski said, "Low power FM stations are small, but they make a giant contribution to local community programming. This important law eliminates the unnecessary restrictions that kept these local stations off the air in cities and towns across the country." The Act states the following: The Federal Communications Commission, when licensing new FM translator stations, FM booster stations, and low-power FM stations, shall ensure that-- (1) licenses are available to FM translator stations, FM booster stations, and low-power FM stations; (2) such decisions are made based on the needs of the local community; and (3) FM translator stations, FM booster stations, and low-power FM stations remain equal in status and secondary to existing and modified full-service FM stations. In General- The Federal Communications Commission shall modify its rules to eliminate third-adjacent minimum distance separation requirements between-- (1) low-power FM stations; and (2) full-service FM stations, FM translator stations, and FM booster stations.
==Rulemaking== In July 2011, the FCC issued a [[notice of proposed rulemaking]] in response to the law. It proposes to put a "floor" on the number of community LPFM stations in each [[media market]], without considering the land area which the market covers. This could be detrimental for community stations in markets with a lower [[population density]], and could result in LPFM stations being pushed into the [[exurb]]s, where more [[channel (communications)|channel]]s are available, but far fewer potential listeners live within a small [[broadcast range]].
A March 19, 2012 FTC ruling appears to address the concern that major corporations using "translator" stations as LPFMs, originating programming that could otherwise only have been heard on [[AM broadcasting|AM]] or on a proprietary digital radio system called [[HD Radio]]. This use, disallowed by the FCC, could have circumvented caps intended to prevent excessive [[concentration of media ownership]], and violates the [[noncommercial educational|noncommercial]], [[local programming|localism]], [[effective radiated power|power]], and [[HAAT|height]] rules that other community LPFM stations must abide by.<ref>RawStory.com, FCC decision strikes critical blow to right-wing radio dominance, March 20, 2012</ref>

The conservatory, which provides secondary education at the general (junior high school) level as well as technical and vocational upper secondary (senior high school/sixth-form college) instruction, has separate schools for music, dance, and theatre."[https://www.icm.gov.mo/en/CM Macao Conservatory]." [[Cultural Affairs Bureau (Macau)|Cultural Affairs Bureau]]. Retrieved on September 13, 2017. Other versions: [https://www.icm.gov.mo/pt/CM Portuguese], [https://www.icm.gov.mo/cn/CM Traditional Chinese], [https://www.icm.gov.mo/gb/CM Simplified Chinese] The schools of music and dance are designated as public secondary school programmes by the [[Education and Youth Affairs Bureau (Macau)|Education and Youth Affairs Bureau]]."[http://appl.dsej.gov.mo/eduenquiry/edu/eduweb/schinf/schlistmain.jsp?a_code=170&sid=&lang=p&sh_year=2016&sh_info=schalvara&sh_a_code=&sh_s_code=&sh_name=&sh_level=&sh_special=&sh_system=O&sh_daynight=&sh_language=&sh_free=&sh_area=&search=1&PubPg=0&advance=0&b_submit=search_2Pesquisar Conservatório de Macau]." [[Education and Youth Affairs Bureau (Macau)]]. {{Infobox software | name = Mattermost | logo = Mattermost logo horizontal.svg | screenshot = Mattermost UI.png | developer = Mattermost Inc | released = {{Start date and age|2015|10|02}} | discontinued = no | programming language = Go | latest release version = 5.4.0 | language count = 11 | license = [[MIT License]] | website = {{URL|https://www.mattermost.com/}} }}
'''Mattermost''' is a [[Open-source software|open-source]], [[Self-hosting|self-hostable]] chat service. It is designed as an internal chat for organisations and companies, and mostly markets itself as an alternative to [[Slack (software)|Slack]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mattermost.org/why-we-made-mattermost-an-open-source-slack-alternative/|title=Why we made Mattermost an open source Slack-alternative {{!}} Mattermost|website=www.mattermost.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref>
The code was originally proprietary, as Mattermost was used as an internal chat tool inside SpinPunch, a game developer studio, but was later open-sourced.<ref name=":0" /> The 1.0 was released on 2.10.2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mattermost.com/blog/mattermost-3-4-16/|title=Open source Slack-alternative reaches 1.0: Self-host ready, Slack-compatible, MIT licensed - Mattermost Private Cloud Messaging|date=2015-10-02|work=Mattermost Private Cloud Messaging|access-date=2018-10-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
The project is maintained and developed by Mattermost Inc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/mattermost|title=Crunchbase|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref> The company generates funds by selling support services and additional features, that aren't in the open-source edition.
There are Clients on [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[MacOS]], and [[Linux]] and for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].
In the media Mattermost is mostly regarded as an alternative to the more popular Slack.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://t3n.de/news/quelloffene-slack-alternative-mattermost-645316/|title=Quelloffene Slack-Alternative zum Selbsthosten: Mattermost 1.0 in der Kurzvorstellung|work=t3n News|access-date=2018-10-21|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://entwickler.de/online/tools/mattermost-184240.html|title=Mattermost - Open-Source-Alternative zu Slack|date=2015-10-23|work=entwickler.de|access-date=2018-10-21|language=de-DE}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.okturtles.org/2015/11/five-open-source-slack-alternatives/|title=Five Open-Source Slack Alternatives » okTurtles Blog|website=blog.okturtles.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@russleyshaw/which-chat-platform-should-i-use-d73f22d558f3|title=Which Chat Platform Should I Use?|last=Shaw|first=Russley|date=2017-05-09|website=Russley Shaw|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref> It also got integrated into [[GitLab]] as "GitLab Mattermost",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://about.gitlab.com/2015/08/18/gitlab-loves-mattermost/|title=GitLab Mattermost, an open source on-premises Slack alternative|date=2015-08-18|work=GitLab|access-date=2018-10-21|language=en}}</ref> although in the mean time GitLab aquired [[Gitter]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/03/15/gitlab-acquires-software-chat-startup-gitter-will-open-source-the-code/|title=GitLab acquires software chat startup Gitter, will open-source the code|date=2017-03-15|work=VentureBeat|access-date=2018-10-21|language=en-US}}</ref> another popular chat tool.
== References == {{Reflist}}

[[Image:Missing link puzzle.jpg|100px|right|thumb|Missing Link puzzle]] '''Missing Link''' is a [[mechanical puzzle]] invented in 1981 by Steven P. Hanson and Jeffrey D. Breslow.
The puzzle has four sides, each depicting a chain of a different color. Each side contains four tiles, except one which contains three tiles and a gap. The top and bottom rows can be rotated, and tiles can slide up or down into the gap. The objective is to scramble the tiles and then restore them to their original configuration.
The two middle rows cannot be rotated. To move tiles in these rows, you need to loop the tiles from one row to another, up and down.
There are 15 tiles and a gap, giving a maximum of 16! arrangements. However, the middle tiles of each four-tile chain are identical, and each position is equivalent to seven other positions obtained by rotating the entire puzzle (about its axis or upside-down), reducing the number of arrangements to 16! / 8 / 8 = 326,918,592,000. If the three long chains are also considered interchangeable, then the number of arrangements is further reduced to 16! / 8 / 8 / 6 = 54,486,432,000.
==See also== *[[Combination puzzles]] *[[Mechanical puzzles]]
==External links== *[http://www.jaapsch.net/puzzles/missing.htm Picture and solution]

{{refimprove|date=November 2009}}
A '''mobile comic''' is a digital [[comic]] or [[comic strip|cartoon strip]] that can be purchased, downloaded, read and sometimes edited or shared with friends via [[mobile phones]].
== Overview == Increasingly the line between digital comics, animation and games is blurring and the same applies to their mobile counterparts as mobile comics become multimedia with sounds and interactivity. In 2008 [[IDW Publishing]] and [[Devil's Due Publishing]] (now Devil's Due Digital) became two of the earliest adopters of comics for mobile devices.<ref>{{cite web|last=Phegley|first=Kiel|title=IDW ON THE CHANGING FACE OF MOBILE COMICS|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=24637|publisher=Comic Book Resource|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> Devil's Due's initially offered mobile comics through companies such as [[Uclick]], on their GoComics Mobile Store.<ref>{{cite web|last=Peres|first=Josh|title=uclick Brings Devil's Due to Cell Phones|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/comics/gocomics/prweb805404.htm|publisher=PR Web|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
Mobile comic content has until recently been miniatuarized or adapted versions of established branded comic content. With the rise of file sharing and piracy it has been increasingly hard for publishers to control money leakage from digital/mobile comics and as such publishers (especially traditional Japanese Manga houses) have shied away from licensing digital or mobile comics.
This however, has led to the rise of user-generated (independent artists) using platforms to publish and sell their work at low cost, and (for the first time in years) do so profitably.
The challenges for mobile comics creation include:
* Small screen size, which means as little text as possible can be included. * Different handsets with different screen sizes and technical specifications means the same java viewer will not work on all phones. * Story telling must end within 25 frames, or less. The number of frames depends on delivery method
Several mobile content providers have now developed their own mobile comics platforms, some using java-based applications which have to be downloaded to the mobile first before comics can be viewed. Others are using Multi Media Messaging and WAP subscription to deliver strips. However, there are platforms for iPhone and iPad that have been developed to distribute RSS-based webcomics for free, such as the iOS application [http://www.appsbergersyndrome.com/Comic_Avenue/pressrelease.html Comic Avenue].
==Titles== Initially the titles released were existing comics licensed for the new medium but new titles are emerging purely on the mobile phone. ''Thunder Road'' is the first original title for the medium, featuring artist Steven Sanders who previously worked on ''[[The Five Fists of Science]]''.<ref>[http://www.silverbulletcomicbooks.com/rage/118457104446937.htm Thunder Road: Comics On Your Phone Should Be Good], Silver Bullet Comic Books</ref><ref>[http://www.gocomics.com/thunderroad/ GoComics Books - Mobile Comic Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=121552 TALKING TO THE THUNDER ROAD CREATORS], July 19, 2007, [[Newsarama]]</ref> ''Carnival of Souls'' is the first digital and motion comic book series on Blackberry's App World, written by Jazan Wild.<ref>[http://crackberry.com/carnival-souls-1st-comic-book-app-app-world/ Carnival of Souls - 1st Comic Book App in App World- Mobile Comic Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/05/carnival-comics-scares-up-downloadable-apps.html Carnival Comics scares up downloadable apps / LA Times ], May 24, 2009</ref> ''The Carrier'' is the first original graphic novel exclusively on the iPhone, written by Evan Young.<ref>[http://www.comicsbulletin.com/news/125362814735622.htm/ The Carrier released: First graphic novel exclusive to iPhone<!-- Bot generated title -->], Sept 22, 2009</ref> ''Alien Revolution'' an eight chapter multi language comic, by Illot.<ref>[http://www.alienrevolution.org Alien Revolution: Multi language.<!-- Bot generated title -->], by Illot 2016</ref>''Mobilecomic'' A collection of comics. Multi language. Interactive, by Illot.<ref>[http://www.mobilecomic.org Mobilecomic.org: A collection of comics. Multi language. Interactive.<!-- Bot generated title -->], by Illot 2017</ref>

revision.text:
'''Mobile gambling''' refers to playing games of chance or skill for money by using a remote device such as a [[tablet computer]], [[smartphone]] or a [[mobile phone]] with a wireless internet connection. Over a hundred mobile casinos are operating as of December 2013, with most of the big casino operators in gambling now providing a mobile platform for their player base.
==Market== In 2005, Jupiter Research forecast that global mobile gambling services would generate revenues of more than $19.3 billion [[US]] dollars by 2009.<ref name=gua1>{{Cite news | last = Hanman | first = Natalie | title = Placing a bet on the mobile | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 10 February 2005 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2005/feb/10/mobilephones.onlinesupplement | accessdate = 22 March 2011 }}</ref> In 2010, [[Gartner]] analysts showed the 2009 global mobile gambling revenues at $4.7 billion and forecast $5.6 billion for 2010.<ref name=gar2010>{{Cite press release | title = Gartner Says Worldwide Mobile Gaming Revenue to Grow 19 Percent in 2010 | publisher = Gartner | date = 17 May 2010 | url = http://www.gartner.com/it/page.jsp?id=1370213 | accessdate = 22 March 2011 }}</ref> Such a large discrepancy between the 2005 forecast and the 2009 reality is attributed to the unexpected 2006 US prohibition of all internet based gambling.
The mobile gambling market, as of 2011 is still in flux. The European Union still does not have a unified mobile gambling legislative framework in place. Each European country has their own set of widely different laws which regulate mobile gambling ranging from Finland where a government monopoly operates internet casinos to Norway which is in favor of complete prohibition of [[online gambling]].
===Market projections=== According to a Juniper Research report<ref name=jr2010>{{Cite press release | title = Mobile Gambling Wagers to Surpass $48bn by 2015 | publisher = Juniper Research | date = 2 September 2010 | url = http://www.juniperresearch.com/viewpressrelease.php?pr=204 | accessdate = 22 March 2011 }}</ref> released in September 2010 the total sum wagered on mobile casino games is expected to surpass $48 billion US dollars by 2015. The report bases this prediction on (1) the high growth rates of mobile casinos, lotteries and sports betting providers in major emerging markets and China; (2) liberalization of mobile gambling legislation in Europe; (3) United States repealing the [[Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006]], permitting people in the US to legally gamble online again.<ref name=jr2010/>
A 2010 Gartner forecast sees 2014 global mobile gambling revenues reach $11.4 billion.<ref name=gar2010/>
==Mobile casino games== According to a February 2010 comScore MobiLens study<ref name=cs2010>{{Cite press release | title = Smartphone Adoption Shifting Dynamics of U.S. Mobile Gaming Market | publisher = comScore Inc. | date = 14 April 2010 | url = http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2010/4/Smartphone_Adoption_Shifting_Dynamics_of_U.S._Mobile_Gaming_Market | accessdate = 22 March 2011 }}</ref> of the U.S. mobile gaming market, smartphone subscribers are much more likely to play mobile casino games than subscribers of generic phones. The study revealed that 7.6% of smartphone subscribers and 1.2% of generic mobile subscribers played mobile casino games within a three-month time frame.<ref name=cs2010/>
Aside from availability online, United States of America-based mobile casino apps have appeared in several land-based locations that can be utilized to gamble only while physically present on the casino's property. This extends to outside areas that are still within the boundaries of the property, making them the first type of slot machine, sports-betting, and random number generated gambling to take place legally off the licensed gaming floor while still inside a U.S. casino.
According to [[VentureBeat]], Google does not allow any real-money gambling apps on its [[Google Play Store]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Betcade launches early access for Android gambling apps|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/12/14/betcade-launches-early-access-for-android-gambling-apps/|publisher=[[VentureBeat]]|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>
In 2013 Apple and Google reversed a decision to permit mobile gambling applications to be distributed by their service in the United States.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Mobile phones}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2011}} '''"My EBT"''' is a [[hip-hop]] song performed by [[Stanley Lafleur]] under the alias "Mr. EBT". The song laments what can be done with an [[Electronic Benefit Transfer]] card (used for financial entitlements in the [[United States]].)
The song and its video became controversial, especially among [[conservative]] pundits, who considered the song a glorification of the country's welfare system.
==Content== The lyrics of "My EBT" are based on real-life examples of welfare abuse that Lafleur had witnessed first-hand. The song laments a person using their sister's E.B.T. card (which is considered to be a fraudulent and hence also abusive use of the card) to acquire a large array of junk food (mostly [[potato chip]]s and [[soft drinks]]) from various stores ("never going hungry, swiping all day"), and attempting to, but failing to also purchase [[marijuana]] and [[alcoholic beverages|alcohol]] on the card as well.<ref name=nydn-myebt>{{cite web|last=Lysiak|first=Matthew|title=Ripped by conservatives, rapper 'Mr. EBT' defends video as parody of welfare abuses|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/09/24/2011-09-24_just_a_dopey_video_dont_rip_me_sez_mr_ebt_its_a_parody.html|publisher=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=27 September 2011}}</ref><ref name=th-benebt/> As an excuse for the actions, the song also states that it is okay because "it's an E.B.T., it ain't food stamps."<ref name=ebt-bh>{{cite web|last=Gharam|first=Michael|title=Life’s a beach on EBT Street|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/opinion/op_ed/view/2011_0922lifes_a_beach_on_ebt_street/srvc=home&position=1|publisher=[[The Boston Herald]]|accessdate=27 September 2011}}</ref>
The song was also accompanied by a music video posted on [[YouTube]], which featured Lafleur going around to various stores to purchase junk food using an E.B.T. card, much like what is described in the song itself.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IGfe2tAUbM</ref>
==Reception== The song gained attention when its music video was posted by the [[Drudge Report]]. Numerous conservative commentators and websites criticized the song and video, complaining that the video "celebrat[ed] the pure coolness of any and all things gotten for nothing", and glorified welfare.<ref name=nydn-myebt/> [[Ben Shapiro]] criticized the song by stating that "it's almost impossible to sum up what's wrong with America's economy while standing on one leg. Unless your name is Mr. EBT", and that he is "the sort of leech who is bankrupting our society."<ref name=th-benebt>{{cite web|last=Shapiro|first=Ben|title=Four Minutes to Explain All That Is Wrong With America|url=http://townhall.com/columnists/benshapiro/2011/09/21/four_minutes_to_explain_all_that_is_wrong_with_america/page/full/|publisher=Townhall.com|accessdate=27 September 2011}}</ref>
In response to the criticism, Lefleur defended the video by saying that the song and video represented the problems with the E.B.T. system and people who abuse it, described as being people who "[rub] the benefit card in the face of taxpayers" (as he portrayed himself doing in the video), thus denying help to those who really need it the most.<ref name=nydn-myebt/>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Nawaz Sharif sidebar}} The '''National Action Plan''' is an [[action plan]] that was established by the [[Government of Pakistan]] in January 2015 to crack down on [[Terrorism in Pakistan|terrorism]] and to supplement the ongoing [[Operation Zarb-e-Azb|anti-terrorist offensive]] in [[North Waziristan|North-Western Pakistan]]. It is considered as a major coordinated state retaliation following the deadly [[2014 Peshawar school massacre|Peshawar school attack]].<ref name="Dawn News, 2014" /><ref name="Washington Times, 2014" /><ref name="Dawn, Haider" /><ref name="Dawn News, Mateen Haider report" /> The plan received unprecedented levels of support and co-operation across the country's political spectrum, inclusive of the federal and provincial governments.
It combines foreign and domestic policy initiatives aimed to crack down on and eventually eliminate [[:Category:Rebel groups in Pakistan|proscribed organisations]] across the country. The plan was provided as the framework for the [[Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan]] which established speedy trial military courts for offences relating to terrorism. It has also led to the resumption of capital punishment and mandatory re-verification through [[fingerprint recognition]] of all subscribers on [[mobile telephony]].<ref name="BBC" />
The National Action Plan authorises the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Foreign]], [[Ministry of Finance (Pakistan)|Finance]], and other ministerial departments to reach out to the [[Special relationship (international relations)|friendly]] Muslim countries to clamp down on financiers of [[Sectarianism in Pakistan|sectarian]] and [[Terrorism in Pakistan|terrorist networks]] operating against [[Pakistan]].<ref name="Express Tribune, 2015" />
==Background== [[File:Army Public School.jpg|thumbnail|Army Public School, KPK]] On 16 December 2014, six gunmen affiliated with the [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan|Tehrik-i-Taliban]] (TTP) conducted a terrorist attack on the [[Army Public School Peshawar|Army Public School]] in the northwestern Pakistani city of [[Peshawar]]. The militants, all of whom were foreign nationals, included one [[Chechen people|Chechen]], three [[Arab people|Arabs]] and two [[Afghanistan|Afghans]]. They entered the school and opened fire on school staff and children,<ref name="BBC"/><ref name="DNA India" /> killing 145 people, including 132 schoolchildren, ranging between eight and eighteen years of age.<ref name="edition.cnn.com" /><ref name="The New York Times" /> A rescue operation was launched by the [[Pakistan Army]]'s [[Special Services Group]] (SSG) special forces, who killed all six terrorists and rescued 960 people.<ref name="BBC" /><ref name="The Express Tribune" />
==Establishment of the plan== On 24 December 2014 political parties conference chaired by the then [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]] reached consensus over the issue of setting up military courts for tackling terrorism cases in the country, along with a wider plan to tackle terrorism.<ref name="Washington Times, 2014" />
{{quote|text=We have to act fast and whatever is agreed we have to implement it immediately...this agreement is a defining moment for Pakistan and we will eliminate terrorists from this country.|sign=Prime Minister Pakistan|source=<ref name="dawn" />}}
On 24 December the Prime Minister (PM) in a televised address to the nation announced the 'National Action Plan' (NAP) to deal with terrorism. According to the Interior Minister, the plan was prepared in the light of the decisions taken by All Parties Conference. For this purpose the PM established the National Action Committee consisting of the members from all the political parties and decision were taken in the light of the recommendations of this committee. The PM's address gave the following outline of the National Action Plan, the points of which were decided in the APC.
The [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaaf]] (PTI) called off the protests and participated in the APC. However, it abstained from voting the bill and amendment. [[Jamiat Ulema-e Islam (F)]] (JUI F) and [[Jamaat-e-Islami]] (JI) also abstained from voting. JI proposed that the word religion should be omitted from the text of the bill. JUI insisted that the word sect is objectionable. The [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) and [[Awami National Party]] (ANP) voted in favour of the bill and amendment.<ref name="LA Times" /><ref name="DNA India" />
==The plan== * After the Peshawar incident, government decided to proceed with the execution of extremists convicted in terror related cases. The Government has already started implementation. * Special courts, headed by the officers of the armed forces, will be established for the speedy trial of terrorists. These courts will be established for a term of two years. * Formation of armed militia will not be allowed in the country. * [[National Counter Terrorism Authority]] will be revived and made effective * There will be a crackdown on hate-speech, and action will be taken against newspapers, magazines contributing to the spread of such speech. * Financial sources of terrorists and terror organisations will be cut. * Banned outfits will not be allowed to operate under different names. * Special anti-terrorism force will be raised. * Measures will be taken to stop religious extremism and to protect minorities. * Madrassas will be regularised and reformed. * Print and electronic media will not be allowed to give any space to terrorists. * Keeping the rehabilitation of IDPs as the top-most priority, administrative and development reforms in [[FATA]] will be expedited. * Communication systems of terrorist organisations will be destroyed. * Social media and the Internet will not be allowed to be used by terrorists to spread propaganda and hate speech, though exact process for that will be finalised. * Like the rest of the country, no space will be given to extremism in any part of the Punjab. * Operation against terrorists in Karachi will be taken to its logical conclusion. * In the interest of political reconciliation, Baluchistan government will be given complete authority by all stakeholders. * Elements spreading sectarian violence will be prosecuted. * Comprehensive policy will be formed for registration of Afghan refugees. * To give provincial intelligence agencies access to communication of terrorists and to strengthen anti-terror agencies through basic reforms in the criminal justice system. Constitutional amendments and legislation will be carried out for this purpose.
==Implementation== * [[Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan]] passed on 7 January 2015. * Over 50 cases of hardcore terrorists for prosecution in military courts send till 25 March 2015. * 55,000 Afghan refugees expelled by between January and 23 March 2015.<ref name="Tribune" /> * Lifted a seven-year-old moratorium on the executions of prisoners sentenced to death. * Executions of 128 prisoners till{{clarify|date=March 2015}} March 2015.<ref name="Decca Chronicle" /> * By March 2015, civilian and intelligence agencies had arrested 150 people, half of them clerics, in violation of laws.<ref name="Tribunbe 2" /> * On 25 March 2015, Pakistan froze a number of accounts used to funnel Rs 10.2 billion in cash to terror suspects. * Boundary walls of all schools up to {{Convert|8|ft}} and topping them with {{Convert|2|ft}} high razor wire. * By 15 March 2015, Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA), has verified more than 70 million SIM's and 11 million were blocked due to not having re-verification.<ref name="The News Teller" /> * From 24 December 2014 to 25 March 2015, law enforcement agencies arrested 32,347 people on different charges in 28,826 operations.<ref name="Tribune 3" /> * On 3 April 2015, at least 76 suspects including two Afghan nationals were arrested in [[Peshawar]].<ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/863641/security-forces-arrest-76-suspects-in-peshawar-raid/ Security forces arrest 76 suspects in Peshawar raid]</ref>
==See also== * [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]]
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="LA Times">{{Cite news|title=Taliban kills at least 104 people in attack on Pakistan military school|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/afghanistan-pakistan/la-fg-pakistan-taliban-attack-20141216-story.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|work= Los Angeles Times|date=16 December 2014}}</ref> <ref
