{{Infobox podcast |title = Serial |image = Serial podcast logo.png |caption = |host = [[Sarah Koenig]] |language = English |website = {{official URL}} |updates = {{Unbulleted list | Thursday morning | Season one: weekly | Season two: | Episode 1–3: weekly | Episode 4–11: every other week | Season three: weekly }} |production = {{hlist|Sarah Koenig|Julie Snyder|Dana Chivvis|Emily Condon}} |audio format = Podcast (via streaming or downloadable MP3) |began = {{Start date|2014|10|3}} |ended = |num_seasons = 3 |num_episodes = 32 |runtime = Variable (27–65 minutes) |genre = {{Unbulleted list | Investigative journalism | Serialized audio narrative }} |cited_for = 2015 Peabody Award |cited_as = "an audio game-changer" |provider = [[WBEZ]] }} [[File:Sarah Koenig, American journalist 2015.jpg|thumb|''Serial'' host and producer [[Sarah Koenig]]]] '''''Serial''''' is an investigative journalism [[podcast]] hosted by [[Sarah Koenig]], narrating a nonfiction story over [[serial (radio and television)|multiple episodes]]. The series was co-created and is co-produced by Koenig and Julie Snyder and developed by ''[[This American Life]]''. Season one investigated the 1999 murder of [[Hae Min Lee]] (Hangul: 이해민), an 18-year-old student at Woodlawn High School in Baltimore, Maryland, U.S. Season two focused on Sergeant [[Bowe Bergdahl]], an American Army soldier who was held for five years by the [[Taliban]], and then charged with [[desertion]]. Season three, which debuted on September 20, 2018, explores cases within courthouses in the Cleveland, Ohio area.https://serialpodcast.org/ New episodes were originally available weekly when a season was active, but partway through the second season the schedule was revised to every other week. ''Serial'' ranked number one on [[iTunes]] even before its debut and remained there for several weeks.{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/sarah-larson/serial-podcast-weve-waiting |title=''Serial'': The Podcast We've Been Waiting For |date=October 9, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |last=Larson |first=Sarah |work=[[The New Yorker]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011221411/http://www.newyorker.com/culture/sarah-larson/serial-podcast-weve-waiting |archivedate=October 11, 2014 |df= }} ''Serial'' won a [[Peabody Award]] in April 2015 for its innovative telling of a long-form nonfiction story.{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/baltimore-insider-blog/bal-serial-peabody-podcasts-20150420-story.html|title='Serial' is first-ever podcast to win Peabody award; creator Sarah Koenig makes Time's 100 most influential people list [Updated]|last=Gorelick|first=Richard|work=baltimoresun.com|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}} As of September 2018, episodes of seasons one and two have been downloaded over 340 million times, establishing an ongoing world record.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/news/serial-season-3-premiere-date-podcast-1202927015/|title=‘Serial’ Season 3 Podcast Premiere Date Set|last=Spangler|first=Todd|date=2018-09-05|work=Variety|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}} The last episode of season two of ''Serial'' was released March 31, 2016. The producers of ''Serial'' launched the podcast ''[[S-Town]]'' on March 28, 2017.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/loved-serial-podcast-sarah-koenig-launch-murder-spinoff-series-ahead-season-three-1594957 | title=Loved Serial podcast? Sarah Koenig to launch 'murder' spinoff series ahead of season three | author=Alicia Adejobi | date=5 December 2016 | publisher=International Business Times | access-date=7 December 2016 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161206160931/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/loved-serial-podcast-sarah-koenig-launch-murder-spinoff-series-ahead-season-three-1594957 | archivedate=6 December 2016 | df= }} Season three's first two episodes were released on September 20, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/serial/status/1042715422485868544|title=Serial on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-09-22|language=en}} In 2018, HBO announced that the network would be adapting the podcast into a docuseries.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/tv-news/hbo-announces-the-case-against-adnan-syed-docuseries-628292/|title=HBO Announces 'The Case Against Adnan Syed' Docuseries|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|date=2018-05-16|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}} == Series overview == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! style="padding: 0 8px;" colspan="2" rowspan="2"| Season ! style="padding: 0 8px;" rowspan="2"| Episodes ! colspan="2"| Originally aired |- ! First aired ! Last aired |- |style="background: #A62821;"| | [[Serial (podcast)#Season 1 (2014)|1]] | 12 | {{Start date|2014|10|3}} | {{End date|2014|12|18}} |- |style="background: #3A54A1;"| | [[Serial (podcast)#Season 2 (2015–16)|2]] | 11 |style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start date|2015|12|10}} | {{End date|2016|03|31}} |- |style="background: #D9C300;"| | [[Serial (podcast)#Season 3 (2018)|3]] | 9 |style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start date|2018|9|20}} | {{End date|2018|11|15}} |- |} Koenig has said that ''Serial'' is "about the basics: love and death and justice and truth. All these big, big things."{{Cite web |url=http://acculturated.com/nprs-absorbing-new-podcast-serial/ |title=NPR's Absorbing New Podcast,''Serial'' |date=October 10, 2014 |accessdate=October 14, 2014 |publisher=Acculturated |last=Olson |first=Marina |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141015171727/http://acculturated.com/nprs-absorbing-new-podcast-serial/ |archivedate=October 15, 2014 |df= }} She also has noted, "this is not an original idea. Maybe in podcast form it is, and trying to do it as a documentary story is really, really hard. But trying to do it as a serial, this is as old as [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]]." ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'' reported that [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller|Phil Lord and Chris Miller]], directors of ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' and the film ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', would be producing a television program about the podcast that will take a "behind-the-scenes approach that details how Koenig went from virtual anonymity to creating one of 2014's biggest cultural phenomenons".{{Cite web|title = 'Serial' the Podcast Will Now Become Serial the TV Show|url = http://www.vulture.com/2015/09/serial-is-being-turned-into-a-tv-show.html?mid=facebook_vulture#|website = Vulture, NYMag.com|accessdate = October 1, 2015|date = |deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151002210257/http://www.vulture.com/2015/09/serial-is-being-turned-into-a-tv-show.html?mid=facebook_vulture|archivedate = October 2, 2015|df = }} ===Season 1 (2014)=== On February 9, 2015, [[Scott Pelley]] of CBS News reported ''Serial's'' Season 1 episodes had been downloaded more than 68 million times.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/new-hope-for-inmate-from-serial-podcast/|title=New hope for inmate from ''Serial'' podcast|date=February 9, 2015|website=CBS News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210055338/http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/new-hope-for-inmate-from-serial-podcast/|archivedate=February 10, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 9, 2015|df=}} By February 2016, the episodes had been downloaded over 80 million times.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/when-a-post-conviction-hearing-feels-like-a-sequel-the-weirdness-of-serial-back-on-the-stand/2016/02/08/b3782c60-2a49-48f7-9480-a34dd9e07ab6_story.html 'Serial' takes the stand: How a podcast became a character in its own narrative] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306070006/https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/when-a-post-conviction-hearing-feels-like-a-sequel-the-weirdness-of-serial-back-on-the-stand/2016/02/08/b3782c60-2a49-48f7-9480-a34dd9e07ab6_story.html|date=2016-03-06}} Washington Post. February 8, 2016 Season 1 investigated the 1999 [[murder of Hae Min Lee]] ({{Korean|hangul=이해민}}), an 18-year-old student at [[Woodlawn High School (Baltimore)|Woodlawn High School]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], U.S. She was last seen at about 3 p.m. on January 13, 1999.{{cite news |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-02-04/news/9902040039_1_baltimore-county-college-of-baltimore-randallstown |title=Information sought on woman missing |date=February 4, 1999 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113040304/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-02-04/news/9902040039_1_baltimore-county-college-of-baltimore-randallstown |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }} Her corpse was discovered on February 9 in [[Gwynns Falls Leakin Park|Leakin Park]] and identified two days later. The case was immediately treated as a homicide.{{cite news |last1=Chang |first1=Young |last2=Hermann |first2=Peter |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-02-12/news/9902120061_1_hae-min-lee-block-of-rockridge-road-lee-s-father |title=Body found in park is missing woman, 18 |date=February 12, 1999 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113040303/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-02-12/news/9902120061_1_hae-min-lee-block-of-rockridge-road-lee-s-father |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }} Lee's ex-boyfriend, Adnan Masud Syed, was arrested on February 28 at 6 a.m. and charged with [[First Degree Murder|first-degree murder]], which led to "some closure and some peace" for Lee's family.{{cite news |last=Oakes |first=Amy |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-03-01/news/9903010074_1_min-lee-young-lee-woodlawn |title=Ex-boyfriend is charged in teen's killing |date=March 1, 1999 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150124194117/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-03-01/news/9903010074_1_min-lee-young-lee-woodlawn |archivedate=January 24, 2015 |df= }} A memorial service for Lee was held on March 11 at Woodlawn High School.{{cite news |last=Apperson |first=Jay |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-03-12/news/9903120122_1_min-lee-lacrosse-woodlawn |title=Slain teen remembered as joyful, 'full of love' |date=March 12, 1999 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129202313/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-03-12/news/9903120122_1_min-lee-lacrosse-woodlawn |archivedate=January 29, 2015 |df= }} Syed's first trial ended in a mistrial, but after a six-week second trial, Syed was found guilty of Lee's murder on February 25, 2000,{{cite news |last=Francke |first=Caitlin |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-02-26/news/0002280318_1_woodlawn-high-min-lee-syed |title=Jury finds teen guilty of killing ex-girlfriend |date=February 26, 2000 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113040247/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-02-26/news/0002280318_1_woodlawn-high-min-lee-syed |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }} and given a life sentence, despite pleading his innocence.{{cite news |last=Francke |first=Caitlin |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-06-07/news/0006070134_1_syed-honors-student-urick |title=19-year-old gets life sentence for killing former girlfriend |date=June 7, 2000 |accessdate=November 20, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113040251/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-06-07/news/0006070134_1_syed-honors-student-urick |archivedate=November 13, 2014 |df= }} Syed did not speak in front of the jury.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/tamara-shayne-kagel/ten-legal-things-people-dont-understand-about-serial_b_6310118.html|title=10 Things People Don't Understand About 'Serial' Unless You're a Criminal Attorney|last=Kagel|first=Tamara Shayne|date=2014-12-24|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-23}} When ''Serial'' Season 1 ended, in December 2014, Syed already had a petition before a higher court. In February 2015, the [[Maryland Court of Special Appeals]] filed a decision allowing Syed to appeal his conviction on grounds his attorney, [[Cristina Gutierrez]], had provided ineffective counsel for failing to seek a plea bargain during his trial. The Court also announced that they would address the question of whether new evidence from Asia McClain, providing an alibi for Syed, would be admitted.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/02/07/md-court-will-allow-adnan-syed-to-appeal-his-conviction-in-serial-case/|title=Md. court allows Adnan Syed to appeal his conviction in ''Serial'' case|last=Phillip|first=Abby|date=7 February 2015|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=7 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208070314/http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/02/07/md-court-will-allow-adnan-syed-to-appeal-his-conviction-in-serial-case/|archivedate=8 February 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} Three months later the case was remanded back to the lower court,{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/05/19/the-case-for-serial-s-adnan-syed-just-got-busted-wide-open|title=The Case for Serial’s Adnan Syed Just Got Busted Wide Open|last=Michaelson|first=Jay|date=2015-05-19|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en}} where Asia McClain and others testified in February 2016. Koenig attended that hearing and produced 3 short "update" episodes of ''Serial'', but this podcast run was abruptly truncated, mid-hearing, when Koenig left to continue production of Season 2.{{Cite news|url=https://slate.com/culture/2016/02/serial-s-season-one-update-episodes-reviewed.html|title=Why Sarah Koenig’s Serial Season 1 Updates From Adnan’s Trial Are So Frustrating|last=Waldman|first=Katy|work=Slate Magazine|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en}} On June 30, 2016, Judge Martin P. Welch granted Syed's motion for post-conviction relief, setting aside the original conviction and calling for a new trial,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/01/us/serial-adnan-syed-new-trial.html|title=Adnan Syed, of ‘Serial’ Podcast, Gets a Retrial in Murder Case|last=Bromwich|first=Jonah Engel|date=June 30, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=July 1, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630221022/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/01/us/serial-adnan-syed-new-trial.html|archivedate=June 30, 2016|deadurl=no|last2=Stack|first2=Liam|issn=0362-4331|df=}} agreeing that it demonstrated ineffective assistance of counsel that Syed's lawyers did not question the interpretation of cellphone tower evidence during the original trial.{{Cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/crime/bs-md-ci-adnan-syed-new-trial-20160630-story.html|title=Conviction vacated, new trial granted for Adnan Syed of 'Serial'|last=Sun|first=Baltimore|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815104952/http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/crime/bs-md-ci-adnan-syed-new-trial-20160630-story.html|archivedate=2016-08-15|deadurl=no|access-date=2016-08-15|df=}} The State appealed and lost when, on March 29, 2018, [[Maryland Court of Special Appeals|Maryland's intermediate appellate court]] upheld the lower court ruling for a new trial, in a 2-1 decision{{Cite web|url=https://www.adnansyedwiki.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/20180329-COSA-Opinion-Syed-Granted-New-Trial-again-State-Appeal-Denied.pdf|title=Opinion of the Court of Special Appeals: State of Maryland vs Adnan Syed. No. 2519, September Term, 2013 and No. 1396, September Term, 2016|last=Woodward|first=Chief Judge Patrick|date=2018-03-29|website=Undisclosed Wiki|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. The State has appealed the case again to [[Maryland Court of Appeals|Maryland's highest court]], on the grounds that defense counsel should not be required to contact a potential alibi witness. The Court of Appeals will reach a decision by August 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/03/29/598001941/serial-subject-adnan-syed-deserves-a-new-trial-appeals-court-rules|title='Serial' Subject Adnan Syed Deserves A New Trial, Appeals Court Rules|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-18|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421163115/https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/03/29/598001941/serial-subject-adnan-syed-deserves-a-new-trial-appeals-court-rules|archivedate=2018-04-21|deadurl=no|language=en|df=}} ====People involved==== * Hae Min Lee – murder victim, 18-year-old high school student and athlete * [[Adnan Syed]] – former boyfriend of Lee who was convicted of killing her, his conviction was overturned in 2016{{cite web|url=https://www.adnansyedwiki.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/20160630-Opinion-Judge-Welch-PCR2-Retrial-Granted-Circuit-Court.pdf|title=Memorandum Opinion II, Circuit Court Baltimore City, June 30, 2016. Adnan Syed vs State of Maryland|last1=Welch|first1=Martin|date=|website=The Undisclosed Wiki|publisher=MD Court of Special Appeals|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 October 2018}} * Jay Wilds{{Cite web|url = https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2014/12/29/exclusive-interview-jay-wilds-star-witness-adnan-syed-serial-case-pt-1/|title = Exclusive: Jay, key witness from Serial, tells his story for the first time|date = December 29, 2014|accessdate = January 4, 2015|website = The // Intercept|last = Vargas-Cooper|first = Natasha|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150103233926/https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2014/12/29/exclusive-interview-jay-wilds-star-witness-adnan-syed-serial-case-pt-1/|archivedate = January 3, 2015|df = }} – key witness at Syed's trial and professed accomplice of Syed{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2830737/New-hope-convicted-murderer-brilliant-high-school-girlfriend-case-cult-podcast-hit-Serial.html|title = Will hit podcast lead to the release of high school killer? Family's new hopes for homecoming king convicted of murdering 'brilliant' secret girlfriend|date = November 13, 2014|accessdate = December 7, 2014|website = Mail Online|publisher = Daily Mail|last = Fagge|first = Nick|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20141113213909/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2830737/New-hope-convicted-murderer-brilliant-high-school-girlfriend-case-cult-podcast-hit-Serial.html|archivedate = November 13, 2014|df = }} * Stephanie McPherson – Jay's girlfriend and close friend and classmate of Syed * Don – Lee's boyfriend at the time of her murder and colleague at Lenscrafters, an eyewear shop * Aisha Pittman – Classmate and Lee's close friend * Jennifer (Jenn) Pusateri – Jay's close friend * Debbie Warren – Lee's friend who said Lee told her she was meeting Don after school * Krista Myers – Classmate and close friend of Lee and Syed, who recalled Syed asked Lee for a ride after school the day she disappeared * Becky Walker – Classmate/friend who remembered Lee and Syed had talked about a ride, who also said she saw Syed after school * "Cathy" – A friend of Pusateri who said she saw Wilds and Syed on the day Lee disappeared * Saad Chaudry – Syed's best friend * Asia McClain – Student at Woodlawn High School and acquaintance of Syed and Lee, said she saw Syed in the library at the time of the murder * Laura Estrada – Classmate who did not believe Syed was guilty, but who did not think Jay would lie about something serious * Nisha – Student from [[Silver Spring, Maryland]] and friend of Syed's, who was called from Syed's phone at 3:32pm, a time during which Syed claimed Jay (who did not know Nisha) had his phone * Yasser Ali – Syed's friend from the mosque * [[Rabia Chaudry]] – friend of Syed's family, older sister of Saad Chaudry, and an attorney, who has been fighting for years to prove Adnan's innocence.{{Cite web|url = http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/537/transcript|title = 537: The Alibi – Transcript|date = October 3, 2014|accessdate = December 5, 2014|website = This American Life|publisher = Chicago Public Media & Ira Glass|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141113041054/http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/537/transcript|archivedate = November 13, 2014|df = }} * "Mr. S" – discoverer of Lee's body in [[Leakin Park]] * Kevin Urick and Kathleen "KC" Murphy – state prosecutors at trial * [[Cristina Gutierrez|M. Cristina Gutierrez]] – Syed's defense attorney * Detectives Bill Ritz and Greg MacGillivary – lead homicide investigators ===Season 2 (2015–16)=== In September 2015, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported the second season would focus on Sergeant [[Bowe Bergdahl]], an American [[United States Army|Army]] soldier who was held for five years by the Taliban, and then charged with desertion. A spokesperson for ''Serial'' only said, "Over the last few months they've been reporting on a variety of stories for both Seasons 2 and 3 of ''Serial'', along with other podcast projects."{{Cite web|title = 'Serial' Podcast to Take Up Bowe Bergdahl Case|url = http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/serial-podcast-to-take-up-bowe-bergdahl-case/|accessdate = September 24, 2015|first = Cara|last = Buckley|publisher = ''The New York Times''|month = |publication-date = September 23, 2015|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150924171006/http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/serial-podcast-to-take-up-bowe-bergdahl-case/|archivedate = September 24, 2015|df = }} The first episode of the season was released, without any previous release date announcement, on December 10, 2015.{{Cite news|title = 'Serial' Season 2 Lets Bowe Bergdahl Tell His Side of Afghan Story|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/11/business/media/serial-season-2-bowe-bergdahl-recalls-his-afghan-odyssey.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = December 10, 2015|access-date = December 10, 2015|issn = 0362-4331|first = Richard A.|last = Oppel Jr|first2 = John|last2 = Koblin|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151210210732/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/11/business/media/serial-season-2-bowe-bergdahl-recalls-his-afghan-odyssey.html|archivedate = December 10, 2015|df = }} For Season 2, Koenig teamed up with Mark Boal, the [[Academy Award]] winning screenwriter of ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' and ''[[Zero Dark Thirty]]'', and his production company, Page 1. Boal had conducted a series of interviews with Bergdahl as part of a film production he was working on, and both Boal and Bergdahl gave Koenig permission to use those excerpts of those recorded interviews in episodes of ''Serial''. As Koenig stated in Season 2's first episode: "They'd come to us saying 'hey, we've been doing all this reporting on the story, and we've also got this tape. Do you think you might want to listen?' And yes, we did, and we were kind of blown away, and so we began working with them. They shared their research with us, and also put us in touch with many of their sources... We don't have anything to do with their movie, but Mark and Page 1 are our partners for Season 2."{{Cite web|title = DUSTWUN|url = https://serialpodcast.org/|accessdate = September 24, 2015|first = Sarah|last = Koenig|publisher = ''Serial''|month = |publication-date = September 10, 2015|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150924053407/http://serialpodcast.org/|archivedate = September 24, 2015|df = }} On December 14, General [[Robert B. Abrams]], head of [[United States Army Forces Command]] at [[Fort Bragg|Fort Bragg, North Carolina]] ordered that Bergdahl face a court-martial on charges of desertion.{{Cite web|title = Bowe Bergdahl to Face Court-Martial on Desertion Charges|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/15/us/bowe-bergdahl-to-face-court-martial-on-desertion-charges.html?_r=0|accessdate = December 14, 2015|first = Richard|last = Oppel, Jr.|publisher = ''The New York Times''|month = |publication-date = December 14, 2015|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151217014613/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/15/us/bowe-bergdahl-to-face-court-martial-on-desertion-charges.html?_r=0|archivedate = December 17, 2015|df = }} Sarah Koenig announced on January 12, 2016, that the podcast schedule would be changed to every other week to allow for deeper reporting, and to add more information than initially planned, with Season 2 Episode 5 released on January 21, 2016.{{Cite web|title = Season 2 Announcement|url = https://serialpodcast.org/posts/2016/01/season-2-announcement|website = Serial|access-date = January 12, 2016|date = January 12, 2015|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305143046/https://serialpodcast.org/posts/2016/01/season-2-announcement|archivedate = March 5, 2016|df = }} Internet radio service [[Pandora Radio]] streamed the second season of ''Serial.''{{Cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3053044/behind-the-brand/pandoras-serial-deal-is-great-news-for-podcast-nerds-and-internet-radio|title=Pandora's "Serial" Deal Is Great News For Podcast Nerds And Internet Radio|last=Titlow|first=John Paul|date=November 2, 2015|website=Fast Company|language=en-US|access-date=November 11, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107045954/http://www.fastcompany.com/3053044/behind-the-brand/pandoras-serial-deal-is-great-news-for-podcast-nerds-and-internet-radio|archivedate=November 7, 2015|df=}} On November 3, 2017, military judge Col. Jeffery R. Nance rendered a verdict dishonorably [[Discharge (military)|discharging]] Bergdahl from the Army, reducing his rank to private, requiring forfeit of some of his pay for ten months and no prison time. The verdict is subject to review by Gen. Robert B. Abrams, and may also be appealed to the United States Army Court of Criminal Appeals.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/03/us/bowe-bergdahl-sentence.html|title=Bowe Bergdahl Is Dishonorably Discharged, but Avoids Prison for Desertion in Afghanistan|last=Oppel, Jr|first=Richard A.|date=November 3, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 3, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103160141/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/03/us/bowe-bergdahl-sentence.html|archive-date=2017-11-03|dead-url=no|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|df=}} After the sentencing, ''Serial'' announced to be working on a "coda" for the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/3/16604444/serial-bowe-bergdahl-podcast-coda|title=Serial will return to talk about Bowe Bergdahl’s sentence|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171104093608/https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/3/16604444/serial-bowe-bergdahl-podcast-coda|archivedate=2017-11-04|df=}} ==== Award ==== In June 2017, the Radio Television Digital News Association announced Season 2 of Serial has won the 2017 National [[Edward R. Murrow Award (Radio Television Digital News Association)|Edward R. Murrow Award]] for a news series and for its website. Murrow Awards are presented in October in New York.{{Cite news|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/166910/rtdna-announces-2017-national-edward-r-murrow-awar|title=RTDNA Announces 2017 National Edward R. Murrow Award Winners|work=All Access|access-date=2017-06-23|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906224622/https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/166910/rtdna-announces-2017-national-edward-r-murrow-awar|archivedate=2017-09-06|df=}} ====Persons involved==== * Sergeant [[Bowe Bergdahl]] – held for five years by the Taliban, then released in May 2014 in exchange for Taliban prisoners held in the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]]. He was court-martialed on charges of desertion and misbehavior before the enemy in December 2015. *Lieutenant John Billings – Bergdahl's platoon leader *[[Mark Boal]] – the [[Academy Award]] winning screenwriter of ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' with whom Bergdahl held most of his interviews *Shane Cross – a friend from the same platoon as Bergdahl *Ben Evans – soldier who had described OP Mest, where Bergdahl operated out of *Darrel Hanson – in the same company as Bergdahl *Kayla Harrison – a friend, and Kim Harrison's daughter *Kim Harrison – a friend Bergdahl identified as his emergency contact *Josh Korder – in the same company as Bergdahl, recorded message for Bergdahl over radio *Austin Landford- soldier whom Bergdahl was supposed to relieve at the end of his shift. It was Landford's noticing Bergdahl's non-presence that notifies the Army that he has gone missing *Mark McQuarry – in the same company as Bergdahl *Mujahet Raman (not his real name) – Taliban who speaks about Bergdahl's capture *Jon Thurman – in the same company as Bergdahl ===Season 3 (2018)=== {{Expand section|date=October 2018}} Season 3 is meant as an analysis of the normal operation of the American criminal justice system, as opposed to Season 1 and 2 that followed "extraordinary" cases.{{Cite web|url=https://serialpodcast.org/season-three/about|title=About Season Three|website=Serial|access-date=2018-09-22}} K.Austin Collins of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' commented that the third season was "an overarching account of an institution: the criminal-justice system, writ large".{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/09/serial-podcast-season-3-review|title=After a Long Break, Serial Has Its Day in Court|last=Collins|first=K. Austin|work=HWD|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}} Koenig has described Season 3 as "a year watching ordinary criminal justice, in the least exceptional, most middle-of-the-road, most middle-of-the-country place we could find: Cleveland." Episodes follow different cases and are taped in [[Greater Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], with particular focus on cases before the [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] [[Ohio Courts of Common Pleas|Court of Common Pleas]] at the [[Justice Center Complex]] in [[Downtown Cleveland]]. Andrew Liptak of ''[[The Verge]]'' commented that Koenig's opening monologue was "stunning, almost cinematic". He added that ''Serial'' is "impossible to ignore in the field" and its first release was a watershed moment for podcasts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/23/17887612/serial-season-3-review-sarah-koenig-cleveland-criminal-justice-system|title=Serial’s third season is a return to form|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-11-07}} ==Episodes== ===Season 1 (2014)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- style="color:white" ! style="background-color: #A62821;" | # ! style="background-color: #A62821;" | Title ! style="background-color: #A62821;" | Length (minutes:seconds) ! style="background-color: #A62821;" | Original release date {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=1 |Title=The Alibi |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|3}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=53|s=28}} |ShortSummary=This episode explores the story of Adnan Syed, who may have been wrongly convicted in 1999 of killing Hae Min Lee, Syed's ex-girlfriend who was a senior at Baltimore County's Woodlawn High School. She disappeared in January 1999. ''Serial's'' investigative team "follows up on long-dormant leads, rechecks alibis, and questions assumptions."{{Cite news |url=http://www.baltimoremagazine.net/2014/10/6/1999-murder-of-baltimore-teen-re-examined-in-new-podcast |title=Baltimore Teen's Murder Re-Examined in New Podcast – Makers of This American Life delve into questions surrounding the 1999 murder of a Woodlawn High School senior |last=Mulvihill |first=Amy |date=October 6, 2014 |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013175929/http://www.baltimoremagazine.net/2014/10/6/1999-murder-of-baltimore-teen-re-examined-in-new-podcast |archivedate=October 13, 2014 |df= }} Host Sarah Koenig reveals that the story is in process and that she doesn't know how it will end.{{Cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/10/03/serial_podcast_this_american_life_spinoff_tells_crime_story_is_riveting.html |title=''Serial'' Is Like Nothing I've Heard or Watched Before |date=October 3, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |last=Mathis-Lilley |first=Ben |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012014558/http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/10/03/serial_podcast_this_american_life_spinoff_tells_crime_story_is_riveting.html |archivedate=October 12, 2014 |df= }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/q/blog/2014/10/10/series-sarah-koenig-julie-snyder/ |title=''Serial'': This American Life's first spin-off explores murder case |date=October 10, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |publisher=CBC |last=Chattopadhyay |first=Piya |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011143739/http://www.cbc.ca/q/blog/2014/10/10/series-sarah-koenig-julie-snyder/ |archivedate=October 11, 2014 |df= }} |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=2 |Title=The Breakup |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|3}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=36|s=28}} |ShortSummary=Adnan Syed and Hae Min Lee had a storybook romance, which was kept secret from their disapproving parents. When Lee broke it off, their friends had conflicting interpretations of Syed's behavior: he was either cool with it and sad, or in a rage and hatching a sinister plot to kill her. Syed consistently proclaims his innocence, but there are puzzling inconsistencies in the set of facts he tells. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=3 |Title=Leakin Park |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|10}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=27|s=34}} |ShortSummary=Lee had been missing for three weeks when a man on his lunch break, referred to as "Mr. S", discovered her body. His account of how he found her body seems suspicious to detectives MacGillivary and Ritz, who questioned him, and his background check reveals some bizarre behaviors, including a series of streaking episodes. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=4 |Title=Inconsistencies |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|16}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=33|s=44}} |ShortSummary=An anonymous caller leads detectives to subpoena Adnan Syed's cell phone records. As a result, the detectives discover calls to Jen, who is a friend of one of Adnan's acquaintances, a weed dealer named Jay. Detectives interview Jen and then Jay, who says Syed told him he killed Lee, and then forced him to help bury her body. Details of Jay's story shifted in some significant ways over four interviews, but the detectives said they were able to corroborate his story using cell phone records. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=5 |Title=Route Talk |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|23}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=43|s=10}} |ShortSummary=Producers Koenig and Chivvis test drive the prosecution's route and timeline of Lee's murder between 2:15, when school let out at the high school, and 2:36, when Jay said Syed called him for pick up in the [[Best Buy]] parking lot and then showed Jay Lee's body in the trunk of her car. While that timeline seems possible, though just barely, evidence from the call logs and records of cell tower pings do not quite align with Jay's testimony about the rest of the afternoon. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=6 |Title=The Case Against Adnan Syed |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|10|30}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=43|s=37}} |ShortSummary=In addition to Jay's testimony, evidence against Adnan Syed included a palm print on a map that could not be dated, and cell phone records. Did Syed ask Lee for a ride after school to get into her car? Koenig goes through all the evidence, including the prosecution's timeline and "some stray things" that don't add up, including a neighbor's story, the testimony of Jay's friend Jen, and the sequence of cell phone calls after Lee disappeared. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=7 |Title=The Opposite of the Prosecution |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|6}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=32 |s=30 }} |ShortSummary=Deirdre Enright, Director of Investigation for the [[Innocence Project]] at the [[University of Virginia School of Law]],{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/2016/01/10/462555705/can-true-crime-stories-interfere-with-old-cases | title=Can True Crime Stories Interfere With Old Cases? | date=10 January 2016 | access-date=14 August 2016 | publisher=NPR | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822182951/http://www.npr.org/2016/01/10/462555705/can-true-crime-stories-interfere-with-old-cases | archivedate=22 August 2016 | df= }} and a team of law students analyze the case against Adnan Syed. Deirdre thinks the evidence against him was "thin". She advises Koenig to keep revisiting all the evidence, allowing uncertainties to remain until there is a tipping point when her questions are resolved. They start with a presumption of Syed's innocence, and ask whether they can discover who really did kill Lee. They find some undeveloped forensic evidence, but Koenig is still uncertain. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=8 |Title=The Deal with Jay |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|13}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=43 |s=56 }} |ShortSummary=How credible was Jay's story? Koenig interviews a jury member, who said Jay seemed like a nice young man and believable. A professional detective says the investigation of Lee's murder was better than average, and Jay had handed the police the case on a platter. Koenig and Snyder visit Jay, who declines an interview. Jay's friend Chris recalls what Jay told him about the murder, a story not consistent with Jay's courtroom version. Why did Jay agree to help Syed? Did Syed coerce Jay and threaten to hurt Jay's girlfriend Stephanie? His friends said Jay had a reputation for lying, but not about important things. Jay's friend Jen says she could understand why Jay might lie about some details, but she believed his story. Back to the question: what was the jury thinking? |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=9 |Title=To Be Suspected |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|11|20}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=47 |s=40 }} |ShortSummary=Koenig reveals she has new information about the call at 2:36. First, Laura claims there were never any pay phones in front of the Best Buy, but Jay's drawing shows a phone booth in front of the Best Buy, and he claimed Syed was standing by that phone booth with red gloves on. Second, Lee's friend Summer says that Lee could not have been dead by 2:36, because she had a conversation with Lee between 2:30 and 2:45. Others also saw Lee after school that day. Third, Asia saw Syed at the library in that same time frame. Sarah Koenig explores Syed's perspective as he was questioned, arrested, tried, and sentenced, as well as his letters to friends about life in prison. She mentions that she has reasonable doubt, not in the legal sense, but in the "normal person" sense. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=10 |Title= The Best Defense is a Good Defense |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|12|04}} |Aux1={{Duration|m= 53 |s= 55}} |ShortSummary=Did anti-Muslim sentiment affect the prosecution? The prosecution argued that Syed's community would help him flee to Pakistan if bail were granted, making suggestions that Syed murdered Lee as religiously motivated killing by a lover with "honor besmirched". Defense attorney Cristina Gutierrez argued that someone else did it, and police did not look beyond Syed. His first trial ended in a mistrial, and in the second trial she cast suspicion on Mr. S and Jay as involved in the crime, but she did not present a clear outline of these arguments or scrutinize discrepancies in the call log timeline. Gutierrez discovered the prosecutor had secured an attorney for Jay – arguably a "benefit" worth money – in connection with his pleading guilty as an accessory and agreeing to testify, but the judge did not agree that this tainted Jay's testimony. Koenig does not believe Cristina Gutierrez intentionally bungled his defense, but within a year after Syed's trial, Gutierrez became very ill, her career collapsed, and she was disbarred. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=11 |Title=Rumors |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|12|11}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=41 |s=25 }} |ShortSummary=Koenig investigates negative rumors about Syed, though the rumors do not directly connect him to Lee's murder, and the most troubling rumors cannot be substantiated. People from his mosque were scared when he was arrested, some describing his story as a cautionary tale. Some believe Syed was duplicitous, capable of committing the crime. One rumor, that he stole money from the mosque, was partially confirmed by four people. Syed admitted taking some money when he was in eighth grade, but his mother found out, and he felt ashamed. Syed had a reputation as a peacemaker, "a good guy", helpful and caring. People who knew him in high school cannot believe he planned Lee's murder. Did Syed "lose it", and nurse feelings of rejection? Could Syed have committed murder in a dissociative state, not knowing he did it? Koenig explores whether Syed has true empathy or anti-social characteristics, and consults with psychologist Charles Ewing, who has interviewed many young murderers. Why does Syed not sound more angry about Jay or other people connected to his case? In an 18-page letter to Koenig, Syed reveals his concern about being perceived as manipulative, and says it doesn't matter how the podcast portrays him. |LineColor=A62821 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=12 |Title=What We Know |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2014|12|18}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=55 |s=37 }} |ShortSummary=After spending over a year researching the case, Koenig still is uncertain what happened the day that Lee disappeared. She reveals new information that happened as a result of people hearing about the podcast: she has spoken with Don, Lee's boyfriend of 13 days at the time of her disappearance, and with Jay's former co-worker, Josh. Koenig reviews the phone records again with her production team and determines that neither Jay's nor Syed's story of that day aligns with the evidence. Unresolved discrepancies also include Jen and Jay's stories about how they disposed of Jay's clothes and boots. Reviewing possible motives for the murder, Koenig and her producers reason that, if Syed is innocent, he had extraordinarily bad luck but several experts who reviewed the case tell them "the case is a mess". Syed's petition in the Court of Special Appeals is still alive but torn between two lawyers, he tells Koenig he will allow the Innocence Project to seek court approval to test the DNA found on Lee's body and a bottle found nearby, possibly pointing to another man, Ronald Lee Moore. Koenig expresses her desire to avoid unsubstantiated speculation and to focus on only the facts. She concludes that from a legal perspective, she would have voted to acquit Syed, although she still nurses doubts. |LineColor=A62821 }} |} === Season 2 (2015–16) === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- style="color:white" ! style="background-color: #3A54A1;" | # ! style="background-color: #3A54A1;" | Title ! style="background-color: #3A54A1;" | Length (minutes:seconds) ! style="background-color: #3A54A1;" | Original release date {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=1 |Title=DUSTWUN |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2015|12|10}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=44|s=24}} |ShortSummary=Private Bowe Bergdahl left his U.S. Army post in Afghanistan in 2009, intending to hike about 20 miles to a larger command center and triggers a "[[DUSTWUN]]" manhunt. In telephone conversations with [[Mark Boal]], an academy award winning filmmaker, Bergdahl said he wanted to report poor leadership at his post and air grievances, but enemy fighters captured him within hours of his disappearance. Sarah Koenig will be using more of the 25 hours of recorded conversations between Bergdahl and Boal to tell his story.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/bowe-bergdahl-released/serial-season-2-debuts-bowe-bergdahl-telling-desertion-story-n477596|title='Serial' Season 2 Debuts With Bowe Bergdahl Telling 'Desertion' Story|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=December 10, 2015|accessdate=December 10, 2015|last1=Ortiz|first1=Erik|last2=Miklaszewski|first2=Jim|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210161638/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/bowe-bergdahl-released/serial-season-2-debuts-bowe-bergdahl-telling-desertion-story-n477596|archivedate=December 10, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/12/10/in-new-serial-podcast-bowe-bergdahl-says-he-likened-himself-to-jason-bourne-before-capture/|title=In new ''Serial'' podcast, Bowe Bergdahl says he likened himself to Jason Bourne before capture|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 10, 2015|accessdate=December 10, 2015|last=Lamothe|first=Dan|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210180726/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/12/10/in-new-serial-podcast-bowe-bergdahl-says-he-likened-himself-to-jason-bourne-before-capture/|archivedate=December 10, 2015|df=}} |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=2 |Title=The Golden Chicken |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2015|12|17}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=59|s=12}} |ShortSummary=The capture of Bowe Bergdahl is recounted by Taliban members present that day and the weeks following. Other Army soldiers discuss the initial recovery efforts and their feelings about Bergdahl following his disappearance. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=3 |Title=Escaping |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2015|12|24}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=54|s=18}} |ShortSummary=Bergdahl said he tried to escape after he was captured, but his first attempt only resulted in about 15 minutes of freedom. He was chained spread-eagle to a bed and blindfolded for about three months. His next escape lasted only eight days, during which he was injured falling off a cliff in the dark. He remained in captivity until Special Forces picked him up in 2014. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=4 |Title=The Captors |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|01|07}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=45|s=1}} |ShortSummary=What was going on with the captors? Bergdahl's description of his captors is confusing, largely because his perspective was from inside a cage, inside a locked room. Koenig interviews [[Kidnapping of David Rohde|David Rohde]], another American held captive by the [[Jalaluddin Haqqani|Haqqani]] network for about seven months, who had been abducted with two Afghan colleagues who could interpret what his captors were saying and doing. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=5 |Title=Meanwhile, in Tampa |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|01|21}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=53|s=26}} |ShortSummary=In 2009, the search for Bergdahl was in hands of two low-level personnel recovery intel analysts for Afghanistan, at [[United States Central Command|CENTCOM]] in Tampa, not a division in-theater. Hostage recovery was not at the top of list of priorities for the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], [[National Security Agency|NSA]], or other intelligence agencies, and resources were consequently not available. Because Bergdahl was held in the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] of Pakistan, there were also complicated diplomatic issues. In 2013, General [[John F. Campbell (general)|John Campbell]] made it a top priority to recover Bergdahl, and Colonel [[Jason Amerine]] audited everything done in Bergdahl's case and in other hostage cases. Agencies such as CENTCOM, [[United States Special Operations Command|SOCOM]], [[United States Department of Defense|DOD]], and the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] seemed to hand off responsibility for recovering not just Bergdahl, but other American hostages as well, making a dysfunctional hostage recovery policy. Koenig observes that frustration was the central theme expressed by those she interviewed, who were struggling against competing interests and limits on what the U.S. is willing risk to get hostages back. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=6 |Title= 5 O'Clock Shadow |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|02|04}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=59|s=57}} |ShortSummary=Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl gave a 380-page statement to General Kenneth Dahl, telling the story of his deployment and what happened when he walked away from his post. Bergdahl had been a good infantry soldier up until that point, who even volunteered for extra duty, a "squared away" soldier. He had become disillusioned at his first post in Alaska after basic training and found Army leadership to be lacking. The mission in Afghanistan was counterinsurgency and nation-building, but many soldiers expressed confusion over doing "humanitarian things," rather than seeking and destroying the Taliban enemy. Bergdahl wanted adventure and action, and was disappointed in his platoon's work. The platoon was assigned a rescue mission, but they were attacked on their return, in a firefight through a ravine, eventually limping back to the post with no losses, but they were upbraided for not shaving for six days. Bergdahl was angry about the battalion commander's misplaced priorities. Bergdahl wanted to "kill the bad guys", and do better at engaging the regular Afghans, but he felt the Army was not fulfilling its counter-insurgency mission. When the battalion was assigned to dig trenches near Moest in 110-degree heat of summer, the battalion commander aggressively berated them for being out of uniform, as a breakdown in discipline. Bergdahl was offended by the punishment, feeling the commander was incompetent, and out of control. He felt he had to cause a DUSTWUN to correct the situation. So was he selfish, or selfless? |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=7 |Title= Hindsight, Part 1 |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|02|18}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=37|s=58}} |ShortSummary= Has Bergdahl been telling the truth about his reasons for walking off base in Afghanistan, or just the version he could live with? Bergdahl says he left because Army leaders were dangerously bad. Dahl concluded Bergdahl's comments were truthful, that his motive was well-meaning, but based on incorrect assumptions. Mark Boal said Bergdahl's conclusions would make sense only to himself. Kayla Harrison described him as an unusual, smart, creative teenager, who forged his own strict, uncompromising moral code, who believed if you know something to be wrong in the world, you must take actions to correct it, and he was "impossibly unrealistic". He had romantic expectations, a rigid code of conduct, and a judgmental perspective. He joined the [[U.S. Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] in January 2006, at age 19. Overwhelmed, he had been hospitalized after a panic attack, and a psychologist had assessed his "mental state significant for situational anxiety", recommending discharge with "diagnosis: adjustment disorder with depression". Bergdahl felt he was being judged by his family as a failure, a black sheep who would not do the right thing. In May 2008, to get a waiver to join the Army, he submitted a medical discharge statement that left out his panic attack, hospitalization, and the doctor's note that before re-enlisting in the military, he needed clearance by a psychiatrist. He didn't tell anyone at home he was joining the Army. He just turned up one day in uniform. Kim Harrison said it was the worst idea ever. Koenig asks, "Should the Army have let Bowe in?” |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=8 |Title= Hindsight, Part 2 |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|02|19}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=36|s=56}} |ShortSummary= Did the Army screw up by accepting Bergdahl after his breakdown in Coast Guard basic training two years earlier? Dr. Elspeth Cameron Ritchie thought the Army waiver was not uncommon because information-sharing among different military branches is incomplete. Dr. Michael Valdevenos thought the Army recruiter should have scrutinized Bergdahl's record more thoroughly. Dahl concluded the recruiter had followed all procedures, but should have included review of his separation action. Mark Boal observed Bergdahl experienced the disillusion of someone who believes in the Army, who just wanted to talk to higher-ranking people in the military about improving command leadership. Bergdahl wanted to be the ideal soldier who fights for a cause he is committed to, who rallies behind trusted military leaders, with a code of honor, loyalty, and self-sacrifice. Bergdahl knew his expectations were unrealistic, but he still defended his vision of the way things should be. Bergdahl's June 27 broadcast e-mail to friends, "Who is John Gault?" referred to the industrialist in ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'', who shut down the world's economy in order to fix it. Dr. Christopher Lang diagnosed Bergdahl as having [[Schizotypal personality disorder]]. Valdevenos concurs that this diagnosis is accurate, describing people who are loners, lack close friends, with perceptual alterations and persistent social anxiety. Bergdahl's paranoia was worse under stress — he believed his commander might send them into a suicide operation. Koenig says this diagnosis makes his story more credible. His judgments about the commander may even be true, that American lives were put at risk to retrieve equipment. For Bergdahl, walking off base was not an absolute boundary, but it was not a rational thing to do. Maj. Margaret Kurtz, the court martial prosecutor, said at the time of his alleged misconduct, Bergdahl was able to appreciate the nature and quality and wrongfulness of his conduct. In other words, mental illness or no, he should be held responsible for his actions. Some soldiers thought Bergdahl's good intentions led to a bad "God-like" decision. Some thought he was lying; some thought he had good intentions, but they still could not forgive his actions. Others didn’t perceive there was danger in the reprimands, like Bergdahl did. His platoon was deeply hurt by his actions. Platoon members would die for each other, and because of that, they had become family together. Bergdahl's actions made them feel their whole deployment lost its meaning. Almost all the soldiers he served with thought he should go to court martial. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=9 |Title= Trade Secrets |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|03|03}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=48|s=46}} |ShortSummary= The U.S. State Department engaged in secret peace negotiations in Munich in 2010 with the Taliban that included a "confidence building" condition: trade Bergdahl for two prisoners at Guantanamo. But negotiator [[Richard Holbrooke]] died before political reconciliation could be achieved. There was a brief hopeful moment with new negotiator Mark Grossman, but then there was stagnation for months, and no progress seemed possible. In May 2011, the Taliban walked away from the talks. Then their demands escalated to include release of five GItmo prisoners, including Mullah Faisal. Setbacks included leaks, bad timing, and "old fashioned screw-ups", including the 2011 assassination of former Afghan president Rabbani. In June 2013 a new Taliban office opened with the flag of the Islamic Emirate, in violation of the agreement with Karzai and U.S. representative James Dobbins. The word "emirate" was also on the wall of the building, which infuriated Karzai. The Taliban withdrew from peace talks, and Bergdahl stayed in captivity for another year. The Pakistan Army was gearing up to bomb Pakistani Taliban in Waziristan, and the U.S. had begun withdrawing troops, so prospects for Bergdahl's release were diminishing. Bergdahl's physical condition was deteriorating. U.S. officials, including Chuck Hagel, negotiated through Qatar, finally negotiating a deal for Bergdahl's release in exchange for the five Taliban prisoners at Guantanamo. On Saturday, May 31, 2014, word finally came that Bergdahl was safe and the trade could proceed. It was a transaction, not part of a larger peace negotiation. The Bergdahls had been assured that their son would not face charges, that his time with the Taliban was punishment enough, so they thought it was over, mission accomplished. Not quite. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=10 |Title= Thorny Politics |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|03|17}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=51|s=36}} |ShortSummary= When Koenig questions people about what bothers them about Bergdahl's case, most say that it has become so political. Was it inevitable that it became so combative? Susan Rice characterized his service with "honor and distinction", which angered the military. Soldiers in his platoon said he walked away, and some from his unit started a "He's not a hero" Facebook page. Fox News interviewed soldiers from Bergdahl's platoon and the story became a juggernaut, with bogus intel from a discredited source even saying Bergdahl had become a Muslim and wanted to be a warrior for Islam. The political right was using the story and the platoon for political purposes, trying to bait President Barack Obama because they had been offended by the Rose Garden ceremony, which they characterized as "a tone-deaf move" on the part of the White House. The President did not recognize the irregularities of Bergdahl's story of or questions about his disappearance, and there was no attempt to get to the bottom of the story. Why did the White House make such a mistake, instead of using an earlier plan to have a quiet event? In retrospect, it was important for the President to own the decision and explain the policy behind it. By law, Congress must be given 30-day notice before Guantanamo detainees are released, but the Department of Defense had taken the lead on the trade, and had not told Congress anything. Leaks could have derailed the fragile deal, jeopardizing Bergdahl's life. Congressional staffers felt they could no longer believe anything from DOD: first, where there had been a collegial relationship before, there was now "unprecedented, profound concern about national security risk…" Second, who signed off on the trade of five Taliban? Third, were they safe to release from Gitmo? The public anger at Bergdahl is personal, wrapped in larger questions about negotiating with terrorists. As a result of this anger, the Republican congress changed the legal wording on Gitmo foreign transfer language, creating a stricter standard as a direct result of the Bergdahl trade, and the administration not telling Congress the truth. Bergdahl also had a lengthy stay in Germany, where "SERE" experts (Survival, evasion, resistance, escape) from the military community planned Bergdahl's reintegration, and debriefs took weeks. Bergdahl was unaware he had become a subject of national interest. One important question has not been addressed: there has been no official report or investigation of whether people died or were injured in the search for Bergdahl. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=11 |Title= Present for Duty |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2016|03|31}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=65 |s=05 }} |ShortSummary= Questions remain about Bergdahl's case. First, people with him during Coast Guard boot camp did not understand how could have enlisted in the Army, given their graphic recollections of his breakdown, which was not a "garden variety panic attack". General Kenneth Dahl wrote that Bergdahl's Coast Guard separation should have been examined more closely. Koenig summarizes: the Army messed up, Bergdahl messed up walking off base, and then there were five years with the Taliban. But that leaves out the reckoning desired by the military. They want an accounting. What was Bergdahl's fault, and what was not? General Michael Flynn, formerly head of the Defense Intelligence Agency, says authoritatively people died on missions to find Bergdahl. But the evidence is not so clear, in spite of the six names from the 501st battalion on missions to find DUSTWUN that have been cited in the media. Other soldiers in his unit were convinced that finding Bergdahl was part of all their missions following his disappearance, so the six deaths were connected to Bergdahl. Some cited resources dedicated to finding him that were not then available to other operations. Sergeant Major Ken Wolfe, however, advised looking "at a map and a timeframe", meaning after 45+ days, Bergdahl was in Pakistan. No infantry unit would be deployed to look for Bergdahl, as it would have required special forces. But what about second- and third-order consequences of his desertion? Wolfe dispels these arguments as "speculation and hypothetical". Perhaps the mission to find Bergdahl was the top cover to justify other unrelated missions the Army units needed to accomplish, as an excuse to gain assets and permission to "get outside the wire". Flynn points out they did not have bullet-proof intelligence on where Bergdahl was. But resources were diverted and people were injured and suffered because of looking for Bergdahl. Who is to blame for variables causing the deaths and injuries in wars? The country signed up for all the things attending war, including disillusioned youth and failing Army recruiting systems. Mark Boal's remaining question: what is an appropriate punishment for Bergdahl, who did not intend to cause harm? The Army treats most deserters who walk away from a base as headcases because it is so dangerous. Ambivalence about Bergdahl reflects societal confusion about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as the war on terror. Bergdahl is still a soldier, now classified as "present for duty". He has an office job at a base in San Antonio, waiting for the Army to decide his fate, just waiting — which he knows how to do. |LineColor=3A54A1 }} |} === Season 3 (2018) === {{Expand section|date=October 2018}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- style="color:white" ! style="background-color: #D9C300;" | # ! style="background-color: #D9C300;" | Title ! style="background-color: #D9C300;" | Length (minutes:seconds) ! style="background-color: #D9C300;" | Original release date {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=1 |Title=A Bar Fight Walks into the Justice Center |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|9|20}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=54}} |ShortSummary= A young woman at a bar is slapped on the butt. So why's she the one in jail? |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=2 |Title=You've Got Some Gauls |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|9|20}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=57}} |ShortSummary= When a judge believes he knows you better than you know yourself. |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=3 |Title=Misdemeanor, Meet Mr. Lawsuit |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|9|27}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=63}} |ShortSummary= The smell of raw marijuana + acting nervous + hands in pockets = ? |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=4 |Title=A Bird in Jail is Worth Two on the Street |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|10|04}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=60 |s=45}} |ShortSummary= What happens when the right evidence points to the wrong man? |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=5 |Title=Pleas Baby Please |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|10|11}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=61 |s=31}} |ShortSummary= Don't tell the judges, but the prosecutors have the most power in the building. |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=6 |Title=You in the Red Shirt |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|10|18}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=51 |s=44}} |ShortSummary= Life after you put a cop in jail. |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=7 |Title=The Snowball Effect |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|10|25}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=56 |s=09}} |ShortSummary= If you listen closely to the trash-talking, you start to get the message. |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=8 |Title=A Madman's Vacation |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|11|08}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=65 |s=39}} |ShortSummary= A teenager decides to cooperate. |LineColor=D9C300 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=9 |Title=Some Time When Everything Has Changed |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|2018|11|15}} |Aux1={{Duration|m=50 |s=43}} |ShortSummary= The state of Ohio decides where Joshua belongs. |LineColor=D9C300 }} |} ==Development and release== The concept for ''Serial'' originated with an experiment in Koenig's basement. Koenig and Snyder had pitched a different idea at a staff meeting for a weekly program on events during the previous seven days, which staff members received without enthusiasm.{{Cite web |url=https://soundcloud.com/lilah-raptopoulos/sarah-koenig-on-unhappy-characters |title=Interview: Sarah Koenig on how ''Serial'' came to be |date=October 9, 2014 |accessdate=November 12, 2014 |website=Soundcloud.com |last=Raptopoulos |first=Lilah |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213021843/https://soundcloud.com/lilah-raptopoulos/sarah-koenig-on-unhappy-characters |archivedate=December 13, 2014 |df= }} When [[Ira Glass]] asked Koenig if she had any other ideas, she mentioned podcasting a story that unfolded over time, a serialized narrative. In an interview with [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']], she explained that each episode would return to the same story, telling the next chapter of a long, true narrative. Episode one of the series was released on October 3, 2014, with additional episodes released weekly online. Glass introduced it as a spinoff of his popular radio program, ''This American Life'', and aired episode one on his show.{{Cite web |url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2014/09/ira-glass-sarah-koenig-julie-snyder-serial-podcast-this-american-life |title=''This American Life'' Channels ''True Detective'' in a New Podcast |date=September 19, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |work=Mother Jones |last=Lurie |first=Julia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014100851/https://www.motherjones.com/media/2014/09/ira-glass-sarah-koenig-julie-snyder-serial-podcast-this-american-life |archivedate=October 14, 2014 |df= }} He explained, "We want to give you the same experience you get from a great [[HBO]] or [[Netflix]] series, where you get caught up with the characters and the thing unfolds week after week, but with a true story, and no pictures. Like ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'', but you can enjoy it while you're driving." ===Music=== [[Nicholas Thorburn]] released the soundtrack for ''Serial ''on October 17, 2014.{{Cite web|url = http://exclaim.ca/News/nick_thorburn_releases_soundtrack_to_podcast_serial|title = Nick Thorburn Releases Soundtrack to Podcast ''Serial''|date = October 17, 2014|accessdate = October 23, 2014|website = exclaim.ca|publisher = |last = Hudson|first = Alex|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141020045432/http://exclaim.ca/News/nick_thorburn_releases_soundtrack_to_podcast_serial|archivedate = October 20, 2014|df = }} It includes fifteen tracks, all short instrumentals, and is available at the [[Bandcamp]] site or streamed from several reviewing sites.{{Cite web|url = http://nickdiamonds.bandcamp.com/|title = Nick Diamonds – Music from ''Serial''|date = October 16, 2014|accessdate = October 23, 2014|website = Bandcamp|publisher = |last = Thorburn|first = Nick|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141015171038/http://nickdiamonds.bandcamp.com/|archivedate = October 15, 2014|df = }}{{Cite web|url = 17, 2014|accessdate = October 23, 2014|website = Consequence of Sound|publisher = |last = Young|first = Alex|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141024093317/http://consequenceofsound.net/2014/10/islands-nick-thorburn-writes-soundtrack-for-serial-podcast-listen/|archivedate = October 24, 2014|df = }} Mark Henry Phillips, who mixes the show, has also provided original scores.{{Cite web|url = https://soundcloud.com/markhphillips/sets/original-score-from-serial-mark-h-phillips|title = Original score from ''Serial''|date = 2014|accessdate = November 21, 2014|website = soundcloud.com|last = Phillips|first = Mark Henry|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141214123734/https://soundcloud.com/markhphillips/sets/original-score-from-serial-mark-h-phillips|archivedate = December 14, 2014|df = }} Musical credits for Season 2 include Thorburn and Phillips, as well as Fritz Myers and staff music editor Kate Bilinski.{{Cite web|title = Music|url = https://serialpodcast.org/music|website = Serial|access-date = January 12, 2016|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160112212723/https://serialpodcast.org/music|archivedate = January 12, 2016|df = }} ===Funding=== ''Serial''{{'}}s launch was sponsored by [[MailChimp]], a frequent podcast advertiser, and salaried staff positions were initially funded by [[WBEZ]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.niemanlab.org/2014/10/this-american-life-tries-to-turn-its-radio-audience-onto-podcasting-with-its-new-show-serial/ |title=This American Life tries to turn its radio audience onto podcasting with its new show ''Serial'' |date=October 3, 2014 |accessdate=October 13, 2014 |work=Nieman Lab |last=O'Donovan |first=Caroline |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007053729/http://www.niemanlab.org/2014/10/this-american-life-tries-to-turn-its-radio-audience-onto-podcasting-with-its-new-show-serial/ |archivedate=October 7, 2014 |df= }} Admitting the podcast was funded from ''This American Life''{{'}}s budget during the launch, producer Koenig noted that ''Serial'' would eventually need to generate its own funding. She said, "Everyone's saying 'It's podcasting! It's internet! ''Of course'' there'll be money somewhere.' We're not exactly sure yet." Dana Chivvis, another producer, observed that, since the industry is still in its infancy, a business model for podcasting has yet to be established.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/serial-this-american-life-podcast/ |title=''This American Life'' debuts its new investigative podcast, ''Serial'' |date=October 4, 2014 |accessdate=October 14, 2014 |website=The Daily Dot |publisher=Daily Dot, LLC |last=Schroeder |first=Audra |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018050346/http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/serial-this-american-life-podcast/ |archivedate=October 18, 2014 |df= }} Towards the end of the first season, producers asked for public donations to fund a second season.{{Cite web|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/serial-podcast-needs-cash-for-second-season-despite-being-one-of-most-popular-shows-ever-9873086.html|title = ''Serial'' podcast needs cash for second season, despite being one of most popular shows ever|date = November 21, 2014|accessdate = November 21, 2014|website = The Independent|last = Griffin|first = Andrew|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141120154433/http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/serial-podcast-needs-cash-for-second-season-despite-being-one-of-most-popular-shows-ever-9873086.html|archivedate = November 20, 2014|df = }} Within a week, the staff of ''Serial'' posted an announcement that a second season has been made possible by donations and sponsorship.{{Cite web|url = http://serialpodcast.org/posts/2014/11/there-will-be-a-season-two-of-serial-thanks-to-everyone-who-donated|title = There will be a Season Two of Serial! Thanks to everyone who donated.|date = November 26, 2014|accessdate = December 4, 2014|website = Serialpodcast|publisher = Chicago Public Media & Ira Glass|last = Condon|first = Emily|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141202035637/http://serialpodcast.org/posts/2014/11/there-will-be-a-season-two-of-serial-thanks-to-everyone-who-donated|archivedate = December 2, 2014|df = }} ==Reception== [[File:Sarah Koenig and the crew of Serial at the 74th Annual Peabody Awards.jpg|thumb|right|Host and Executive Producer Sarah Koenig accepts the [[Peabody Award]] for ''Serial''. She is joined on stage by Julie Snyder, Dana Chivvis, Emily Condon, Cecily Strong and Ira Glass.]] ===Season 1 (2014)=== The first season of ''Serial'' was both culturally popular and critically well received. ''Serial'' was ranked at No. 1 on iTunes even before it débuted, leading iTunes rankings for over three months, well after the first season ended.{{Cite news|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/us/artists/podcast/this-american-life/podcasts/serial/|title=iTunes podcast charts|date=February 2, 2015|publisher=itunescharts.net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151216091541/http://www.itunescharts.net/us/artists/podcast/this-american-life/podcasts/serial/|archivedate=December 16, 2015|df=}} It also broke records as the fastest podcast ever to reach 5 million downloads at Apple's [[iTunes store]].{{cite news|last1=Dredge|first1=Stuart|title=Serial podcast breaks iTunes records as it passes 5m downloads and streams|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/nov/18/serial-podcast-itunes-apple-downloads-streams|accessdate=3 April 2015|publisher=The Guardian|date=18 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150326120657/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/nov/18/serial-podcast-itunes-apple-downloads-streams|archivedate=26 March 2015|df=}} [[David Carr (journalist)|David Carr]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' called ''Serial'' "Podcasting's first breakout hit."{{cite news|last1=Carr|first1=David|title='Serial,' Podcasting's First Breakout Hit, Sets Stage for More|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/24/business/media/serial-podcastings-first-breakout-hit-sets-stage-for-more.html|accessdate=3 April 2015|publisher=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150330045414/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/24/business/media/serial-podcastings-first-breakout-hit-sets-stage-for-more.html|archivedate=30 March 2015|df=}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized it as a "new genre of audio storytelling".{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/oct/10/serial-this-american-life-sarah-koening |title=''This American Life's'' first spinoff podcast: 'I don't know where it will end' |last=Raptopoulos |first=Lilah |date=October 10, 2014 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=October 12, 2014 |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013174759/http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/oct/10/serial-this-american-life-sarah-koening |archivedate=October 13, 2014 |df= }} Introducing a ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' segment about ''Serial'', [[Judy Woodruff]] noted that it is "an unexpected phenomenon", and [[Hari Sreenivasan]] mentioned it has "five million downloads on iTunes, far more than any other podcast in history".{{Cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/serial-mania-says-growing-popularity-podcasts/|title = What 'Serial'-mania says about the growing popularity of podcasts|date = December 11, 2014|accessdate = December 12, 2014|website = PBS NEWSHOUR|publisher = NewsHour Productions LLC|last = |first = |deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141212030652/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/serial-mania-says-growing-popularity-podcasts/|archivedate = December 12, 2014|df = }} Calling the characters "rich and intriguing", ''[[The Daily Californian]]'' noted similarities to the film ''[[The Thin Blue Line (1988 film)|The Thin Blue Line]]'' (1988), and described the podcast as "gripping" and the story as "thrilling", while applauding the series for giving "listeners a unique opportunity to humanize the players".{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailycal.org/2014/10/10/serial-podcast/ |title=Review: ''Serial'', a captivating new podcast |date=October 10, 2014 |accessdate=October 13, 2014 |website=[[The Daily Californian]] |publisher=The Independent Berkeley Student Publishing Co., Inc. |last=Schultz |first=Anya |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013163204/http://www.dailycal.org/2014/10/10/serial-podcast |archivedate=October 13, 2014 |df= }} ''Slate''{{'}}s reviewer pointed out that ''Serial'' is not escapist and went on to note: "Someone in the show is not telling the truth about something very sinister. That's the narrative tension that makes ''Serial'' not only compelling but also unlike anything I can remember watching or reading before." ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' commented on the inherently riveting subject matter and noted that the top-notch reporting and podcast format yield "a novel twist on the investigative long-form piece". A critique from the journalism community was more qualified. First noting that some people believe there is a "podcast renaissance", the reviewer from [[Nieman Foundation for Journalism|Harvard's Nieman Journalism Lab]] observed that even though podcasts are not new, they are not yet mainstream. Not all critiques of the podcasting format have been as equivocal. ''[[PopMatters]]'' observed that podcasting is a new distribution model, very different from television as a distribution model because it gives users access to media and the freedom to listen to episodes of a long-form story while doing other things. The reviewer applauded the focus on long-form journalism and added, "Suddenly you feel like the full promise of podcasting has just been unleashed. That long-form narrative nonfiction is really the way to best leverage the potential of podcasting as a distribution model."{{Cite web|url = http://www.popmatters.com/feature/186862-the-flash/|title = The Iconographies – John Woo Said "For a Better Tomorrow:" CW's ''The Flash'' and ''This American Life's Serial''|date = October 13, 2014|accessdate = October 15, 2014|website = PopMatters|publisher = PopMatters.com|last = Q|first = shathley|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141015134402/http://www.popmatters.com/feature/186862-the-flash/|archivedate = October 15, 2014|df = }} A ''Wall Street Journal'' critic observed: "podcasts have slipped marketers' minds. [[ZenithOptimedia]], for example, put out a forecast predicting 0% growth for the medium after years of positive momentum."{{Cite web|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2014/11/05/serial-podcast-marketing/|title = ''Serial'' Is The Hottest Show Of The Fall — Do Marketers Need a Podcast Strategy?|date = November 5, 2014|accessdate = November 12, 2014|website = The Wall Street Journal|publisher = Dow Jones & Company, Inc.|last = Perlberg|first = Steven|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141111052932/http://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2014/11/05/serial-podcast-marketing/|archivedate = November 11, 2014|df = }} Discussing the economics of podcast advertising, ''[[New York Magazine]]'' noted that the personal nature of the podcast format allows higher advertising rates: "CPM (the cost to an advertiser per thousand impressions, a standard ad-industry unit) was between $20 and $45. Compare that to a typical radio CPM (roughly $1 to $18) or network TV ($5 to $20) or even a regular old web ad ($1 to $20), and the podcast wins."{{Cite web|url = http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/10/whats-behind-the-great-podcast-renaissance.html|title = What's Behind the Great Podcast Renaissance?|date = October 30, 2014|accessdate = November 12, 2014|website = New York – Daily Intelligencer|publisher = New York Media LLC|last = Roose|first = Kevin|deadurl = no|archiveurl = commented on the addictive nature of ''Serial.''{{Cite web|url = http://niemanstoryboard.org/stories/serial-podcast-producers-talk-storytelling-structure-and-if-they-know-whodunnit/|title = ''Serial'' podcast producers talk storytelling, structure and if they know whodunnit|date = October 30, 2014|accessdate = November 12, 2014|website = NiemanStoryboard|publisher = Nieman Foundation for Journalism
